scenario: An office wellness team runs a randomized trial during morning break for two weeks: on each day, participating employees are randomly assigned to receive either a cup of caffeinated coffee or a similar-tasting decaf beverage. Immediately after the break, all participants complete the same short alertness questionnaire about the following hour. Averaged over the study period, the caffeinated-coffee group reports higher alertness than the decaf group.
claim: Drinking caffeinated coffee during the morning break increases office workers' alertness in the following hour.
label: YES

X.name: Receiving caffeinated coffee during morning break (randomized)

Y.name: Self-reported alertness in the following hour

Z: Baseline sleep quality / prior-night sleep
Morning workload intensity

causal_structure: X is randomized (coffee vs decaf), so any systematic difference in Y between groups supports a causal effect of X on Y; Z may affect Y but should not systematically differ by X under randomization.
key_insight: Random assignment with a placebo-like control makes confounding unlikely, so the observed difference supports the causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees randomly assigned to receive caffeinated coffee versus a control (decaf/placebo) during morning break?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the randomized caffeinated-coffee group reports higher subsequent alertness than the control group, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the randomized groups show no difference (or the caffeinated group is lower), this study does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: because employees were randomly assigned to caffeinated coffee versus a decaf control and the caffeinated group reports higher alertness afterward, the scenario provides experimental evidence consistent with coffee increasing alertness.
gold_rationale: This is S1 (RCT): random assignment and a control condition directly support the causal claim given the reported higher alertness in the treated group.

scenario: A company pilots a controlled policy change for one month: some teams are instructed to implement two scheduled 5-minute breaks each afternoon, while matched teams keep their usual routines (no scheduled breaks). Teams keep the same projects and deadlines during the month. At the end of each workday, employees complete the same short fatigue survey. The break-policy teams report lower end-of-day fatigue on average than the teams without scheduled breaks.
claim: Scheduling regular short breaks during the workday reduces end-of-day fatigue among office workers.
label: YES

X.name: Having scheduled short breaks during the workday (policy change)

Z: Baseline workload intensity / role demands
Manager flexibility / break culture by team

trap.subtype_name: Change X while holding other factors constant

causal_structure: Teams are matched and asked to keep similar projects/deadlines while only break scheduling differs; this controlled ablation supports X -> Y if the matching/controls are credible.
key_insight: When the policy is the main systematic difference between comparable teams, lower fatigue is evidence consistent with a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Were the break-policy and control teams comparable (matched) and operating under similar project/deadline conditions during the month?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If matched teams truly faced comparable workload/deadlines and only the scheduled-break policy differed, then lower fatigue in break teams supports the causal claim (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If teams differed substantially in workload, management, or deadlines in ways not controlled, the observed difference could be confounded and the causal claim is not supported (AMBIGUOUS).

wise_refusal: Supported conditional on the stated matching: the scenario claims comparable teams with similar projects/deadlines except for the break policy, and the break-policy teams report lower fatigue—consistent with breaks reducing fatigue.
gold_rationale: This matches S4 (controlled ablation): the intervention toggles scheduled breaks while holding other conditions similar, and the reported lower fatigue supports the causal claim as stated.

scenario: A survey of public transportation users asks whether they listen to music during their commute and how stressed they feel during the commute. The survey summary does not clearly describe whether respondents were sampled from morning commutes, evening commutes, or both. Results show that respondents who report listening to music also report lower commute stress.
claim: Listening to music during a commute reduces stress among public transportation users.
label: AMBIGUOUS

Z: Sampling frame / commute time-of-day included (morning vs evening vs both)

causal_structure: If commute time-of-day influences both music listening and stress, then an unclear sampling frame makes it unclear what population the X–Y relationship refers to and whether it generalizes.
key_insight: Without a clear sampling frame/target population, even a reported correlation can’t cleanly support a causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Which commute periods were included in the survey sample (morning, evening, or both), and is the claim intended to generalize to all public-transport commutes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey sampled a well-defined population (e.g., all public-transport commutes across times) and still found lower stress among music listeners, the claim would remain uncertain causally but the association would be well-defined (AMBIGUOUS without causal identification).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the sampling frame is restricted/unknown while the claim is about all users, the claim is underspecified and remains AMBIGUOUS.

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the survey reports lower stress among music listeners, but it doesn’t specify the sampling frame (morning/evening/both). Without knowing what population is represented (and given this is observational), the causal claim can’t be confidently evaluated.
gold_rationale: Because the sampling frame is unclear and the evidence is purely observational, the causal claim is not clearly supported; the case is ambiguous.

scenario: A company analyzes only employees who both attended an annual innovation workshop and received high performance reviews. Within this restricted group, they observe that employees who work overtime tend to receive more promotions. The analysis does not include employees who did not attend the workshop or did not receive high reviews.
claim: Working overtime causes employees to receive more promotions.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the analyzed sample (attended workshop AND high review)

causal_structure: The analysis conditions on a selected subset (workshop attendance + high review). Conditioning on selection related to advancement can induce or distort an overtime–promotion association, so the observed within-sample relationship does not support the causal claim.
key_insight: Conditioning on a selected subgroup can manufacture or distort correlations, making a causal conclusion invalid.
hidden_timestamp: Is the reported overtime–promotion pattern computed only within a subgroup defined by workshop attendance and high reviews (i.e., conditioned on selection)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the relationship were evaluated on the full employee population (without conditioning on workshop attendance/high review) and still held after appropriate controls, the causal claim could be assessed (AMBIGUOUS given this information is absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given the analysis conditions on a highly selected subset, the observed association can be selection-induced and does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the company computes the relationship only within a selected subgroup (workshop attendees with high reviews). Conditioning on selection can distort the overtime–promotion relationship, so the evidence described does not justify the causal claim.
gold_rationale: This is W1 selection bias: conditioning on a selected subset can induce biased X–Y relationships, so the causal claim is not supported by the described analysis.

scenario: A survey is conducted only among employees who received a promotion in the past year. Within this promoted group, those who report working overtime also report higher job satisfaction than those who were promoted without overtime. No non-promoted employees are surveyed.
claim: Working overtime increases job satisfaction among employees.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the survey (only promoted employees)

trap.subtype_name: Surveying only a selected subset (promoted employees)

causal_structure: The sample is restricted to promoted employees; conditioning on promotion can distort the overtime–satisfaction relationship and prevents inferring a causal effect in the overall employee population.
key_insight: A subgroup-only survey can’t justify a population-wide causal conclusion.
hidden_timestamp: Does the survey include only promoted employees (i.e., does it condition on promotion status)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey sampled all employees (promoted and not) and overtime preceded satisfaction measurement, then the relationship could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS because those data are not provided).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given the survey samples only promoted employees, selection can distort the relationship and the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: because the survey includes only promoted employees, the observed overtime–satisfaction relationship may be selection-driven and does not support the causal claim for all employees.
gold_rationale: W1 selection bias: sampling only a selected subgroup (promoted employees) prevents valid causal inference about all employees.

scenario: A survey is conducted among people who have voluntarily resigned from their jobs within the last month. Respondents are asked about their job satisfaction before leaving, and most report low satisfaction. The survey includes only recent quitters.
claim: Low job satisfaction causes employees to quit their jobs.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the sample (only people who quit are surveyed)

causal_structure: Because only quitters are observed (selection on Y), the dataset cannot compare satisfaction levels among non-quitters, so it cannot support a causal claim about quitting.
key_insight: Sampling only outcome cases prevents estimating whether X differs between those with and without Y.
hidden_timestamp: Does the survey include employees who did not quit (non-quitters) for comparison?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both quitters and non-quitters were surveyed and satisfaction was measured before quitting, then the relationship could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS given this evidence is absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given only quitters are sampled, the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: surveying only people who quit provides no comparison group of non-quitters, so the evidence cannot support the causal claim that low satisfaction causes quitting.
gold_rationale: W1 selection bias: selection on the outcome (only quitters observed) prevents valid inference about the satisfaction–quitting relationship in the full employee population.

scenario: A survey is conducted among employees who were promoted. Within that promoted group, those who attended leadership workshops report higher job satisfaction than those who did not. Only promoted employees were invited to the survey.
claim: Attending leadership workshops increases job satisfaction among employees.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the survey (only promoted employees)

causal_structure: The association is estimated only among promoted employees; conditioning on promotion can bias the observed relationship between workshops and satisfaction relative to the full workforce.
key_insight: Evidence from a selected subgroup can’t justify a causal claim about everyone.
hidden_timestamp: Are non-promoted employees included in the survey used to support the claim?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis included a representative employee sample (promoted and not) and workshop attendance preceded satisfaction measurement, the causal claim could be assessed (AMBIGUOUS given missing evidence).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given the survey includes only promoted employees, selection may distort the relationship and the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: because the survey is restricted to promoted employees, the observed workshop–satisfaction pattern may be selection-driven and does not support a causal effect for all employees.
gold_rationale: W1 selection bias: subgroup-only sampling (conditioning on promotion) can distort relationships and prevents valid causal inference about the entire employee population.

scenario: A survey is sent to employees after promotion decisions are announced. Among respondents who were promoted, many report working longer hours after the promotion; employees who were not promoted report fewer hours. The survey does not record hours worked before the promotion decision.
claim: Working longer hours increases an employee's chance of being promoted.
label: NO

X.name: Working longer hours (measured after promotion decisions)

Z: Post-promotion role demands / new responsibilities (promotion can increase hours)

causal_structure: Y (promotion) occurs before X is measured; promotion can increase responsibilities and hours (Y -> X), so the observed pattern can reflect reverse causation rather than X -> Y.
key_insight: If the exposure is measured after the outcome, the direction can be reversed.
hidden_timestamp: Were hours measured before or after the promotion decision?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If hours were measured before promotion decisions (and promotions occurred later), the relationship could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS without additional controls).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given hours are measured after promotions are decided, the evidence is consistent with promotion causing longer hours, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: because hours are measured only after promotions are decided, the observed relationship can be explained by promotion increasing hours (reverse causation), so the evidence does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: W9 reverse causation: the temporal ordering is inconsistent with X causing Y in the described data; instead Y can cause measured X.

scenario: A company finds that, overall, remote workers have lower average performance scores than office workers. But when the data is split by department, remote workers in each department have higher performance scores than their in-office peers. Departments differ in size and baseline performance, and remote-work rates vary by department.
claim: Working remotely reduces employee performance.
label: NO

Z: Department (composition differs; remote-work rates vary by department)

causal_structure: Z (department) affects both X and Y. The aggregate relationship differs from (and reverses) the within-department relationship, so the aggregate comparison is misleading for a causal claim.
key_insight: If every subgroup shows the opposite pattern, the aggregate conclusion is a Simpson’s paradox trap.
hidden_timestamp: Does the direction of the remote–performance relationship reverse when stratifying by department?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the claim were strictly about the aggregate descriptive pattern only, it could describe the combined data but still would not establish causality (AMBIGUOUS for a causal claim).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the claim is interpreted as a general causal effect across comparable employees (within department), it is contradicted because within each department remote workers score higher; thus the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: this is Simpson’s paradox—overall averages suggest remote workers score lower, but within every department remote workers score higher. Aggregating across departments yields a misleading basis for a causal claim.
gold_rationale: W8 Simpson’s paradox: department composition drives the reversal; the aggregate pattern does not support the stated causal conclusion.

scenario: A randomized study at an office provides participants with either caffeinated coffee or decaf each morning for one week, assigned at random. Workers then rate their alertness during the workday using the same survey each day. The caffeinated group reports higher average alertness than the decaf group.
claim: Drinking caffeinated coffee in the morning increases office workers' alertness during the workday.
label: YES

X.name: Receiving caffeinated coffee in the morning (randomized)

Z: Baseline sleep quality / chronotype

causal_structure: X is randomized (caffeinated vs decaf), so differences in Y support a causal effect of caffeine on alertness; Z may affect Y but should balance across arms under randomization.
key_insight: Randomization + control provides direct evidence consistent with a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was coffee (caffeinated vs control) randomly assigned before measuring alertness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the randomized caffeinated group reports higher average alertness than the control group, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the randomized groups show no difference, the study does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: participants were randomly assigned to caffeinated coffee versus a decaf control and the caffeinated group reports higher alertness, consistent with coffee increasing alertness.
gold_rationale: S1 (RCT): random assignment and the reported difference support the causal claim.

scenario: A company reviews employee satisfaction scores and finds that, overall, remote workers report lower satisfaction than in-office workers. However, when the data is split by department, remote workers in each department consistently report higher satisfaction than their in-office colleagues. The overall trend reverses within departmental subgroups.
claim: Working remotely reduces employee satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Department (composition differs; remote-work rates vary by department)

causal_structure: Department influences both remote-work prevalence and satisfaction. The aggregate relationship reverses within each department, so the aggregate comparison is misleading for a causal claim.
key_insight: A single aggregate trend can be the opposite of every subgroup trend (Simpson’s paradox).
hidden_timestamp: Does the remote–satisfaction relationship reverse when stratifying by department?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the claim were only a descriptive statement about the aggregate average, it could describe the combined dataset but would not establish causality (AMBIGUOUS for a causal claim).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the claim is interpreted as a general causal effect among comparable employees (within department), it is contradicted because within every department remote workers report higher satisfaction; thus the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: this is Simpson’s paradox—overall remote workers report lower satisfaction, but within each department remote workers report higher satisfaction. The aggregate pattern is misleading and does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: W8 Simpson’s paradox: the aggregate association reverses within strata, so the causal claim is not supported by the evidence described.

scenario: A survey asks office workers whether they drink coffee and how alert they feel in the afternoon. The survey does not clarify whether “afternoon alertness” was rated on a day when they had already consumed coffee, nor whether “drinking coffee” means daily coffee, occasional coffee, or coffee specifically that day.
claim: Drinking coffee increases afternoon alertness among office workers.
label: AMBIGUOUS

X.name: Coffee consumption (unclear: frequency vs that-day use)

Z: Measurement ambiguity: unclear definition and timing for X and Y

causal_structure: Because X and Y are not operationalized (what counts as coffee use and when Y is measured relative to coffee), the intended X–Y relationship is not well-defined, so a causal claim cannot be evaluated.
key_insight: If X/Y aren’t defined, you can’t even tell what causal question is being asked.
hidden_timestamp: Does X refer to coffee consumed that same day before the afternoon rating, or general coffee-drinking frequency—and when exactly is Y measured relative to coffee intake?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If X is clearly defined as coffee consumed before the afternoon rating on the same day and Y is measured afterward, then the causal question is well-posed but still not answered by the provided summary (AMBIGUOUS).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X/Y remain undefined with unclear timing/frequency, the causal claim is not well-posed (AMBIGUOUS).

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the survey doesn’t define whether X is that-day coffee use or general frequency, and it doesn’t anchor Y relative to coffee timing. Without clear variable definitions, the causal claim can’t be evaluated.
gold_rationale: Key measurement/operationalization details are missing, so the causal claim cannot be reliably interpreted and remains ambiguous.

scenario: A company survey asks respondents whether they work from home and to rate their job satisfaction. The results summary does not report the composition of respondents (e.g., full-time employees vs contractors vs part-time), nor whether response rates differ across these groups.
claim: Working from home increases job satisfaction among employees at the company.
label: AMBIGUOUS

Z: Unclear respondent composition/representativeness (full-time vs contractor vs part-time; possible differential response)

trap.subtype_name: Who is in the dataset is unclear

causal_structure: If different worker types differ in both WFH prevalence and satisfaction, then an unknown sample composition/response pattern makes it unclear what population the X–Y relationship refers to and whether it supports the claim.
key_insight: If you don’t know who responded, you don’t know what claim the data can support.
hidden_timestamp: Do we know which worker types responded (and in what proportions) and whether the survey represents employees at the company?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the survey response is representative of employees (similar response rates across worker types) and X precedes Y measurement, then the causal question is clearer but the causal claim still isn’t established by a simple survey summary (AMBIGUOUS).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If respondent composition/representativeness is unknown, the claim about 'employees at the company' is underspecified and remains AMBIGUOUS.

wise_refusal: Ambiguous: the survey doesn’t report who responded or whether the sample represents employees. Without a clear sampling frame/composition, the causal claim can’t be evaluated reliably.
gold_rationale: Because the respondent population is not specified and the evidence is observational, the causal claim cannot be confidently supported and remains ambiguous.

scenario: A gym has limited spots in popular group fitness classes. New members who sign up are assigned to class spots by lottery when demand exceeds capacity; those who do not win a spot work out alone. After one month, both groups complete the same motivation-to-exercise survey. Members who won the class lottery report higher motivation on average than those who did not.
claim: Attending group fitness classes increases motivation to exercise among gym members.
label: YES

X.name: Attending group fitness classes (lottery assignment when oversubscribed)

causal_structure: Lottery allocation among interested applicants makes winners and non-winners comparable in expectation; differences in Y support a causal effect of attending classes on motivation.
key_insight: A lottery creates a credible counterfactual comparison group.
hidden_timestamp: Were class spots allocated quasi-randomly (by lottery) among members who wanted to join when demand exceeded capacity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If lottery winners (attendees) report higher motivation than lottery non-winners after one month, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there is no difference between lottery winners and non-winners, the causal claim is not supported by this setup (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: because class spots were assigned by lottery among interested new members and winners report higher motivation than non-winners, the scenario provides quasi-random evidence consistent with classes increasing motivation.
gold_rationale: S3 lottery/quasi-random assignment: random allocation among applicants supports the causal claim given the reported higher motivation among winners.

scenario: A randomized study of office workers assigns participants each morning for two weeks to either receive caffeinated coffee or a similar-tasting decaf beverage (control). Later in the day, everyone rates their alertness using the same survey. Across the study, the caffeinated group reports higher alertness on average than the control group.
claim: Drinking caffeinated coffee increases alertness during the workday among office workers.
label: YES
causal_structure: Random assignment to caffeinated vs decaf creates comparable groups; higher alertness in the caffeinated group supports a causal effect of caffeine on alertness.
key_insight: An RCT provides direct evidence for the causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Was coffee exposure randomized with a control group before measuring alertness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the randomized caffeinated group reports higher alertness than the control group, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If randomized groups do not differ, the study does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: the scenario describes random assignment to caffeinated coffee versus a decaf control and reports higher alertness in the treated group, consistent with a causal effect.
gold_rationale: S1 (RCT): random assignment and the reported difference support the causal claim.

scenario: A university sleep clinic studies graduate students during a finals week. Students keep their usual schedules but are randomly assigned to one of three caffeine doses at 9:00am each day for five days: 0 mg (decaf), 100 mg (one small coffee), or 200 mg (two coffees). Students then complete the same 1:00pm alertness test and a self-reported alertness rating. The clinic reports a clear dose-response pattern: average afternoon alertness scores are lowest in the 0 mg group, higher in the 100 mg group, and highest in the 200 mg group. The clinic also notes a plausible mechanism: caffeine blocks adenosine receptors and reduces perceived sleepiness in the hours after consumption.
claim: Higher morning caffeine dose increases afternoon alertness among graduate students during finals week.
label: YES

X.name: Morning caffeine dose (0mg vs 100mg vs 200mg; assigned)

Z: Finals-week sleep deprivation level
Adenosine receptor blockade reducing sleepiness (mechanism)

causal_structure: Dose is assigned and Y shows a monotone gradient; the mechanism (adenosine blockade) provides a plausible pathway. Contextual variation in sleep deprivation affects Y but should not systematically track assigned dose.
key_insight: Mechanism + monotone dose-response is strong evidence consistent with a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Do the results show a consistent dose-response (0mg < 100mg < 200mg) and is a plausible mechanism described linking caffeine to alertness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If alertness increases monotonically with assigned dose and the mechanism is plausible, the causal claim is supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there is no dose-response (or the pattern is inconsistent) or the assignment/mechanism is not credible, the evidence does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: Supported: students were assigned to different caffeine doses, a clear monotone dose-response in alertness is reported, and a plausible mechanism is provided, all consistent with higher caffeine dose increasing alertness.
gold_rationale: S5 evidence: assignment plus dose-response gradient and mechanism jointly support the causal claim.

scenario: A news article compares two cities and reports that the city with a higher number of public parks per capita also has a lower average stress score among residents, based on a citywide wellness survey. The article then concludes that, for individual residents, living near more parks is associated with lower personal stress. The report provides only city-level averages (parks per capita and average stress) and does not include any resident-level data about who lives near parks or their personal stress.
claim: Living near more parks reduces an individual's personal stress.
label: NO

Z: Evidence is only city-level averages (parks per capita and average stress)

trap.subtype_name: Using aggregate correlation to claim individual effect

causal_structure: The evidence is aggregate (city-level) while the claim is individual-level. City-level correlations do not identify individual-level causal effects.
key_insight: You can’t infer an individual causal effect from group averages.
hidden_timestamp: Is the evidence only aggregate (city-level) while the claim is about individual residents?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If resident-level data showed individuals with greater park proximity have lower stress (within comparable contexts), the claim could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS here because such data are absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the evidence remains only city-level averages while asserting an individual-level effect, this is an ecological fallacy and the claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the article uses only city-level averages but makes an individual-level causal claim. Inferring an individual effect from aggregate correlations is an ecological fallacy.
gold_rationale: W5 ecological fallacy: aggregate correlation does not establish an individual-level causal effect, so the claim is not supported by the described evidence.

scenario: A productivity blog analyzes only employees who stayed at the company for at least two years. In this “2+ year survivors” group, the blog reports that employees who frequently take on high-visibility projects also tend to have higher job satisfaction scores. The blog does not include employees who left the company within two years and does not report whether leavers differed in satisfaction or project assignments.
claim: Taking on high-visibility projects increases job satisfaction among employees.
label: NO

Z: Selection into the analysis (only employees who remained employed for 2+ years)

trap.subtype_name: Analysis excludes those who left (failures missing)

causal_structure: Conditioning on being employed 2+ years selects on survival/retention; if leaving relates to satisfaction and/or project assignment, the observed survivor-only relationship can be distorted.
key_insight: Survivors can look different from the full population, creating misleading causal stories.
hidden_timestamp: Does the analysis exclude employees who left within two years (i.e., does it observe only 'survivors')?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis included both stayers and leavers and measured projects before (and satisfaction after), the claim could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS because those data are absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given only 2+ year survivors are analyzed while the claim is about all employees, survivorship bias can distort the relationship, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: the blog analyzes only employees who stayed at least two years. Excluding leavers can distort the projects–satisfaction relationship, so the survivor-only evidence does not support the causal claim for all employees.
gold_rationale: W2 survivorship bias: selection on retention can bias the observed relationship, making the causal claim unsupported by the described analysis.

scenario: A community health newsletter surveys people who choose to attend a weekly “wellness walk” group. The survey reports that attendees who regularly go on the wellness walk tend to have lower resting heart rate than adults in the neighborhood who do not attend. The newsletter does not account for the fact that many attendees also report exercising outside the group and following healthier diets, and participation is voluntary.
claim: Participating in the weekly wellness walk group reduces resting heart rate in the neighborhood.
label: NO

X.name: Participating in the weekly wellness walk group (voluntary)

Z: Health-conscious lifestyle / baseline fitness motivation
Diet quality / exercise outside the group

trap.subtype_name: People who choose X also do other health-promoting behaviors

causal_structure: Health-conscious traits and behaviors (Z) increase likelihood of joining the walk group (X) and also reduce resting heart rate (Y), confounding the observed association.
key_insight: Self-selection by healthier people can create a fake 'treatment effect.'
hidden_timestamp: Is participation voluntary and correlated with other healthy behaviors (diet/exercise) that also lower resting heart rate?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If participants and non-participants were comparable in baseline fitness/lifestyle (or assignment to the group were random) and attendees still had lower heart rate, the claim could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS because that evidence is absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given participation is voluntary and attendees also report healthier diets/exercise, healthy user bias can explain the pattern, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No: participation is voluntary and likely attracts more health-conscious people who also exercise more and eat healthier, which can lower resting heart rate. That confounding (healthy user bias) means the evidence does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: W3 healthy user bias: self-selection into the program is correlated with other health behaviors that affect heart rate, so the causal claim is not supported by the described comparison.

scenario: Maria normally wakes at 6:30 AM when her alarm rings and arrives on time. One morning, a power outage prevented the alarm from ringing, she woke at 8:00 AM, and arrived late. Nothing else unusual is mentioned about her commute that day.
claim: Had Maria’s alarm rung as usual, she would not have been late for work that day.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: alarm did not ring (due to outage)
variables.X': alarm rang at 6:30 AM as usual
Z: Outage-caused disruptions besides the alarm (e.g., transit disruptions)
Maria’s usual commute conditions on comparable weekdays

trap.subtype_name: A single disruption flips outcome unless another independent delay also occurs

causal_structure: Deterministic chain: alarm → wake time → departure time → lateness, with a potential additional outage→lateness path.
key_insight: The counterfactual is only valid if the outage affected lateness solely by preventing the alarm, not via any independent delay.
hidden_timestamp: Besides preventing the alarm from ringing, did the outage cause any other delay that would make her late even if she woke at 6:30?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the outage only prevented the alarm and commute conditions were otherwise normal, then the counterfactual is YES (she would have woken at 6:30 and arrived on time as usual).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the outage also caused an independent delay (e.g., transit disruption) that would still make her late even with a 6:30 wake-up, then the counterfactual is NO.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL: it depends on whether the outage created any independent cause of lateness besides disabling the alarm.
gold_rationale: The story supports a deterministic alarm→lateness mechanism, but without explicitly ruling out other outage-related delays, the claim’s truth depends on that missing detail.

scenario: A company surveys only employees who were promoted last year and asks whether they took a time-management course. Promoted employees who took the course report higher satisfaction, and the company extrapolates to employees who did not take the course. Non-promoted employees are not observed at all.
claim: Had the employees who did not take the time-management course taken it, their job satisfaction would have been higher.
label: INVALID

variables.X: did not take the time-management course
Z: Promotion (sample restricted to promoted employees)
Performance/manager ratings and related traits affecting both course-taking and satisfaction

trap.subtype_name: Counterfactual derived from a selected (promoted-only) sample

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL because key alternative-world details (train delays, whether Asha would catch the train, and departure timing) are missing. Without these constraints, the scenario cannot determine whether the train world would yield on-time arrival.
gold_rationale: The claim hinges on unobserved facts about the train world and Asha’s timing; since those are not specified, the counterfactual cannot be resolved unconditionally.

scenario: Morgan missed a friend’s call (Y) and later says: “If I had cared more (X'), I would have answered immediately.” The scenario does not state whether Morgan’s phone had battery, whether Morgan was in a meeting, or whether the call notification was received.
claim: If Morgan cared more (X'), Morgan would have answered the call immediately (Y').
label: INVALID

variables.X: Morgan cared less about the friend
variables.X': Morgan cared more about the friend
Z: Phone access constraints (battery, do-not-disturb, no signal)
Morgan’s availability (meeting, driving, asleep)
Whether Morgan saw/heard the call notification

trap.subtype_name: Counterfactual about caring without observing feasibility constraints

causal_structure: Immediate answering depends on unobserved feasibility (access/availability/notification). Caring is latent and cannot deterministically imply Y.
key_insight: A motive-based counterfactual is unsupported without knowing what was possible at the time.
hidden_timestamp: The scenario provides no information about whether Morgan had phone access or perceived the call.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Morgan had phone access, noticed the call promptly, and was free to answer, and caring reliably leads to immediate answers for Morgan, then the counterfactual becomes more plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it is unknown whether Morgan had access/availability or even noticed the call (as written), then the counterfactual is NO because constraints could prevent immediate answering even under X'.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is NO given the scenario: it asserts what would happen under a different internal state (caring) without any evidence about feasibility (phone access, availability, notification). Those constraints could still prevent immediate answering in the X' world, so the scenario does not support the claim.
gold_rationale: Because unobserved constraints can determine the outcome independently of caring, the counterfactual claim is not justified from the observed missed call alone.

scenario: After buying a pricey gadget and later feeling regret (Y), Noor says: “If I were more responsible (X'), I would not have bought it.” The scenario does not state Noor’s budget constraints, whether the purchase was needed for work, whether there was a return window, or whether Noor had prior plans to buy it.
claim: If Noor were more responsible (X'), Noor would NOT have bought the gadget (Y').
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Noor was less responsible with spending
variables.X': Noor was more responsible with spending
Z: Budget constraints and financial obligations at the time
Whether the gadget was necessary (work/urgent need)
Return policy and Noor’s knowledge of it
Noor’s planned intention to buy before the moment

trap.subtype_name: Counterfactual about a trait without observing situational constraints and preferences

causal_structure: The purchasing decision depends on latent traits and situational constraints/preferences that are not specified, so the alternative world is underspecified.
key_insight: You cannot deduce a trait-based counterfactual without the decision context (needs, constraints, alternatives).
hidden_timestamp: The scenario omits critical context about Noor’s constraints and needs at the time of purchase (budget, necessity, prior intention).

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Noor had no urgent need, the purchase was impulsive, and being responsible would lead Noor to avoid such discretionary spending, then the counterfactual is YES.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the gadget was necessary (e.g., required for work) or Noor had already planned the purchase within budget, then the counterfactual is NO because the purchase could still occur even under X'.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL because the scenario lacks the decision context (budget, necessity, prior intention). Without those constraints, we cannot determine whether increased responsibility would have changed the purchase decision in the X' world.
gold_rationale: A trait-based counterfactual requires information about the situational choice set and constraints; since these are missing, the claim cannot be resolved unconditionally.

scenario: At a group dinner, Casey forgets to bring a promised dessert (Y). A friend says: “If Casey respected us (X'), Casey wouldn’t have forgotten.” But Casey received an urgent call about a family emergency while leaving home and left immediately.
claim: If Casey respected the group more (X'), Casey would NOT have forgotten the dessert (Y').
label: INVALID

Z: Urgent family emergency call while leaving home
Time pressure and attention diversion

trap.subtype_name: External constraint can determine behavior regardless of internal state

causal_structure: An external shock (emergency) can cause forgetting regardless of respect level, so changing the internal attribution does not ensure Y changes.
key_insight: Attribution-based counterfactuals fail when a strong external constraint can produce the same behavior under X'.
hidden_timestamp: Casey received an urgent family emergency call while leaving home, creating time pressure and distraction.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the emergency call caused distraction/time pressure sufficient to make forgetting likely regardless of respect, then the counterfactual is NO because Casey could still forget under X'.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there was no emergency and the only reason for forgetting was lack of care/respect, then the counterfactual could become more plausible.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is NO given the scenario: an urgent family emergency is a strong external constraint that could cause forgetting regardless of respect. Because that constraint would still apply in the X' world, the scenario does not support the claim that greater respect would prevent forgetting.
gold_rationale: A sufficient external cause (emergency-induced distraction) breaks the implied link between respect and the outcome, so the motive-based counterfactual is not justified.

scenario: During a meeting, Dana gives a short reply to a colleague’s idea (Y). The colleague says: “If Dana valued me (X'), Dana would have responded warmly.” But Dana had just learned of a sudden deadline and was simultaneously messaging their manager about an urgent deliverable.
claim: If Dana valued the colleague more (X'), Dana would have responded warmly in the meeting (Y').
label: INVALID

Z: Acute deadline pressure discovered right before/during meeting
Divided attention (urgent messages to manager)

trap.subtype_name: Behavior explained by situational pressure rather than a stable attitude

causal_structure: Situational pressure affects tone/response; internal valuation may not dominate behavior under acute constraints.
key_insight: Attribution counterfactuals are unsupported when situational constraints can drive the same behavior under X'.
hidden_timestamp: Dana had acute deadline pressure and divided attention during the meeting.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If deadline pressure and divided attention drove the curt response (as described), then the counterfactual is NO because Dana could still respond briefly even under X'.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there was no deadline pressure and Dana’s tone reliably reflects valuation, then the counterfactual could become more plausible.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is NO given the scenario: a situational constraint (acute deadline pressure) plausibly explains Dana’s short reply and could still produce the same behavior even if Dana valued the colleague highly. The scenario therefore does not support the claim.
gold_rationale: Because an external situational driver can account for Y independent of X, the motive-based counterfactual is not justified from the observed behavior.

scenario: Lee didn’t attend a friend’s birthday party (Y). The friend says: “If Lee were a true friend (X'), Lee would have come.” But Lee was stuck on a delayed flight due to weather and was still in the air during the party.
claim: If Lee were a true friend (X'), Lee would have attended the party (Y').
label: INVALID

variables.X: Lee was not a true friend
Z: Flight delay due to weather (physical impossibility)
Being in transit during party time

trap.subtype_name: Physical constraint makes the alternative-world behavior infeasible

causal_structure: A physical constraint (being on a delayed flight) prevents attendance regardless of friendship level, so X does not determine Y here.
key_insight: Attribution-based counterfactuals fail when the hypothesized behavior is infeasible under the constraints.
hidden_timestamp: Lee was on a delayed flight and was in the air during the party, making attendance infeasible.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Lee was physically unable to attend due to flight delay (as described), then the counterfactual is NO because even a true friend could not attend.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Lee was not constrained by travel and simply chose not to attend, then friendship could plausibly influence attendance, making the claim more plausible.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is NO as written: the scenario describes a physical constraint (weather-related flight delay) that prevents attendance regardless of Lee’s friendship level. Because that constraint would still hold in the X' world, the scenario does not support the claim.
gold_rationale: When the outcome is infeasible due to external constraints, changing internal motives or traits does not ensure the behavior changes, so the attribution-based counterfactual is unjustified.

scenario: A customer receives a short email reply from support (Y) and says: “If the company cared about customers (X'), they would have replied more thoughtfully.” The scenario also states that the support system was down for hours and agents were instructed to send only brief templated replies to clear the backlog.
claim: If the company cared about customers (X'), the company would have replied more thoughtfully (Y').
label: INVALID

variables.X: the company cared less about customers
Z: Support system outage and backlog policy
Instruction to send templated replies to clear backlog
Agent workload constraints

trap.subtype_name: Organizational constraint explains behavior regardless of underlying attitude

causal_structure: Organizational constraints (outage/backlog policy) determine reply format; attitude toward customers does not uniquely determine Y.
key_insight: Attributing a constrained behavior to care/intent is invalid when policy constraints can force the same outcome under X'.
hidden_timestamp: Support agents were instructed to send templated replies due to a system outage and backlog.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the outage/backlog policy forced templated replies (as described), then the counterfactual is NO because the same constraint could apply even if the company cared.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there were no outage/backlog policy and agents had full capacity to respond, then caring could plausibly affect reply quality, making the claim more plausible.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is NO under the scenario: a system outage and backlog policy constrained reply quality, which could produce the same brief response even if the company cared about customers. The scenario therefore does not support the motive-based claim.
gold_rationale: Because an external organizational constraint can determine Y independent of X, the observed behavior does not justify the counterfactual about caring.

scenario: Rae posts a negative review about a local business (X). The owner says: “If you hadn’t posted that (X'), we couldn’t sue you for defamation (Y).” The scenario does not specify whether the review asserts false statements of fact vs opinion, whether there were damages, or which jurisdiction applies.
claim: If Rae had NOT posted the review (X'), the business could NOT sue Rae for defamation (Y').
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X': did not post the negative online review
variables.Y: being sued for defamation / viability of a defamation claim
Z: Whether the review contains false statements of fact vs protected opinion
Whether provable harm/damages exist
Jurisdiction-specific defamation standards
Distinction between 'can file a lawsuit' vs 'has a viable claim'

trap.subtype_name: Defamation viability depends on falsity, damages, and jurisdiction; 'can sue' is ambiguous

causal_structure: Legal viability depends on omitted legal/factual elements and on the meaning of 'can sue' (file vs viable).
key_insight: Legal counterfactuals are conditional on missing statutory elements and on definitions (filing vs winning).
hidden_timestamp: The scenario omits whether the review is false fact vs opinion, whether damages exist, and the jurisdiction/standard for defamation.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the review asserted false facts causing measurable harm under the applicable jurisdiction, then posting could support a viable defamation claim, and not posting would remove that particular basis (though filing vs viability still differs).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the review is clearly opinion/true and the jurisdiction requires falsity and damages, then the claim that it is 'not viable' becomes more plausible; however, the statement 'could not sue' remains ambiguous because parties can often file even weak claims.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL because the scenario omits key legal elements (false statement of fact, damages, jurisdiction) and the phrase 'could sue' is ambiguous (file vs viable claim). Without those details, the counterfactual cannot be resolved unconditionally.
gold_rationale: Defamation liability is not determined by posting a negative review alone; it depends on falsity, damages, and jurisdiction, and the claim conflates filing with legal viability. Missing elements prevent a definitive answer.

scenario: Jordan uploads a 15-second clip of a TV show to social media (X). A friend says: “If you hadn’t uploaded it (X'), you couldn’t be sued for copyright infringement (Y).” The scenario does not specify the jurisdiction, whether the clip is transformative, whether it qualifies as fair use/fair dealing, or whether the platform already had a license.
claim: If Jordan had NOT uploaded the TV clip (X'), Jordan could NOT be sued for copyright infringement (Y').
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X': did not upload the TV show clip
variables.Y: being sued for copyright infringement / viability of an infringement claim
Z: Jurisdiction and applicable copyright regime (fair use vs fair dealing)
Whether the clip is transformative/commentary
Whether the platform/user had a license or permission
Distinction between being sued (filed) vs liability/viability

trap.subtype_name: Copyright risk depends on fair use/licensing/jurisdiction; 'can sue' is ambiguous

causal_structure: Legal risk depends on omitted legal elements; not uploading removes one factual basis but does not clarify what 'could be sued' means.
key_insight: Legal counterfactuals require specifying legal tests (fair use) and the meaning of the outcome (file vs viable).
hidden_timestamp: The scenario omits jurisdiction, licensing status, and whether the use qualifies as fair use/fair dealing.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If uploading the clip is unlicensed and not protected by fair use under the applicable regime, then uploading could create infringement risk, and not uploading would remove that basis (though being sued vs liability still differs).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the clip is covered by a license or qualifies as fair use, then a viable infringement claim may be unlikely; however, the claim 'could not be sued' still depends on whether the outcome means filing or a likely-to-succeed lawsuit.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL because the scenario omits key legal determinants (jurisdiction, fair use/licensing) and uses 'could be sued' ambiguously. Without those details, we cannot determine whether not uploading would eliminate meaningful legal risk or whether the statement is about filing vs viability.
gold_rationale: Copyright liability depends on context, licensing, jurisdiction, and fair-use analysis. Missing these elements prevents a definitive counterfactual judgment.

scenario: During a confrontation, Avery pepper-sprays someone (X) and later says: “If I hadn’t used pepper spray (X'), I would have been charged with assault (Y).” The scenario does not specify whether there was an imminent threat, whether Avery could retreat, local self-defense laws, or whether the force used was proportional.
claim: If Avery had NOT used pepper spray (X'), Avery would have been charged with assault (Y').
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: used pepper spray during a confrontation
variables.X': did not use pepper spray during the confrontation
Z: Whether there was an imminent threat
Proportionality of force
Duty-to-retreat / ability to retreat (jurisdiction)
Police/prosecutor discretion and evidence (witnesses, video)

trap.subtype_name: Charging outcomes depend on threat, proportionality, jurisdiction, and discretion

causal_structure: Legal outcomes depend on omitted factual predicates (threat/proportionality) and discretionary enforcement, so the counterfactual cannot be resolved from the scenario.
key_insight: Whether an action leads to criminal charges is conditional on legal standards and discretionary decisions not provided.
hidden_timestamp: The scenario omits key self-defense facts and jurisdictional rules that determine whether charges would apply.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If there was no imminent threat or force was disproportionate under the applicable law, then using pepper spray could increase charge risk, but whether charges are filed still depends on evidence and discretion.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there was an imminent threat and the force was proportionate and lawful self-defense, then charges may be unlikely; however, the scenario still cannot guarantee the absence/presence of charges without jurisdiction and evidence details.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL because the scenario lacks the legal and factual predicates that determine charging (imminent threat, proportionality, retreat rules, jurisdiction, and evidence). Charging is also discretionary. Without these details, the scenario cannot settle whether Avery would have been charged under X'.
gold_rationale: Criminal charging depends on legal elements and discretionary enforcement not specified. Missing those makes the counterfactual about being charged under no pepper spray indeterminate.

scenario: After an employee posts a critical comment about their employer online (X), the employer fires them (Y). A coworker says: “If you hadn’t posted that (X'), they couldn’t have fired you (Y').” The scenario does not specify whether the employee is at-will, whether the comment is protected activity, union status, jurisdiction, or whether there were prior performance issues.
claim: If the employee had NOT posted the comment (X'), the employer could NOT have fired the employee (Y').
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: posted a critical comment about the employer online
variables.X': did not post the critical comment about the employer online
Z: At-will vs for-cause employment status
Whether the speech is legally protected activity
Jurisdiction-specific labor protections / union contract
Pre-existing performance issues or other firing grounds

trap.subtype_name: Termination legality depends on employment status, jurisdiction, contracts, and protected activity

causal_structure: Whether an employer 'could' fire depends on legal/contractual context and other grounds, which are not specified.
key_insight: Legal counterfactuals require specifying the governing regime; otherwise 'could' is ambiguous (legal permissibility vs practical ability).
hidden_timestamp: The scenario omits key employment-law context (at-will vs contract, jurisdiction, protected activity, and other grounds).

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the employee is at-will and not covered by a contract/union protections, then the employer may be able to fire for many reasons, so the claim 'could not have fired' is likely NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the employee is protected by a contract/union or the speech is protected and firing would be unlawful without the post, then the claim becomes more plausible, but still depends on jurisdiction and other possible grounds.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL because the scenario omits crucial legal context (at-will status, contracts/union protections, jurisdiction, protected activity, and other firing grounds). Without that, we cannot determine whether the employer legally could have fired the employee under X'.
gold_rationale: Termination permissibility varies widely by jurisdiction and employment status and may depend on other grounds. Missing context prevents a definitive counterfactual conclusion.

scenario: A manager increases the frequency of team meetings to improve employee productivity. Productivity rises at first, but over several months employees become fatigued and productivity drops below the earlier level.
claim: If we increase the frequency of team meetings, employee productivity will consistently improve.
label: NO

Y.name: Employee productivity over the following months

Z: Employee fatigue / meeting overload
Time-varying adaptation (short-run vs long-run response)

causal_structure: Increasing meetings (X) may raise coordination and short-run productivity (Y), but also increases fatigue (Z) which later reduces productivity; the effect changes over time via feedback/adaptation.
key_insight: A single, monotone do(X) claim can fail when the effect reverses over time due to feedback/adaptation.
hidden_timestamp: After several months (once fatigue/adaptation accumulates), is average productivity still higher than the pre-change baseline?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If fatigue accumulates and long-run productivity falls back to (or below) baseline, the claim of consistent improvement is false.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If fatigue is prevented (e.g., meeting load redesigned) and productivity stays higher over months, the claim could hold in that modified setting.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that increasing meeting frequency will consistently improve productivity because adaptive fatigue can create feedback over time, reversing the effect in the long run.
gold_rationale: The intervention can raise productivity initially but also induces fatigue that later lowers productivity, so the causal effect is time-varying. A claim of consistent improvement ignores feedback/adaptation and is therefore invalid as stated.

scenario: A company evaluates whether a work-from-home policy increases productivity. They analyze only employees who remained employed after the policy, excluding those who left or transferred. Among the remaining employees, productivity appears higher after the policy.
claim: If we assign employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Remaining employed / observed after the policy (retention/attrition)
Reasons for leaving (e.g., poor fit with WFH)

causal_structure: If attrition after the policy depends on productivity or WFH fit, restricting to survivors (Z) biases the estimated effect of assignment (X) on productivity (Y).
key_insight: Excluding leavers can manufacture an apparent benefit because only “survivors” are measured.
hidden_timestamp: Did less-productive (or poor-fit) employees disproportionately leave/transfer after the WFH policy and get excluded from the analysis?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If attrition is related to productivity/WFH fit and leavers are excluded, the observed increase is biased and does not justify the causal claim for all employees.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If everyone is followed regardless of attrition (or attrition is unrelated to productivity) and groups are comparable, the causal claim would be more plausible.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute higher productivity to assigning work from home because the analysis excludes employees who left; survivorship/attrition can bias the comparison.
gold_rationale: Restricting to employees who remained after the policy conditions on a post-policy selection process. If leaving is related to productivity or WFH suitability, the remaining sample is biased, so the do(X) effect is not identified.

scenario: A company evaluates a work-from-home program by analyzing only employees who voluntarily opted in. They compare those employees’ productivity before and after switching. Employees who did not opt in are excluded.
claim: If we allow employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Opt-in participation (self-selection into the program)
Motivation / job role suitability / home setup (pre-existing differences)

causal_structure: Employees who opt in (Z) may differ in motivation/suitability that also affects productivity (Y), so comparing opt-ins pre/post does not identify the causal effect of assignment (do(X)).
key_insight: Voluntary participation selects a non-comparable group, so the observed change can reflect who opted in rather than the intervention effect.
hidden_timestamp: Did employees opt into WFH based on traits (motivation/suitability) that also predict productivity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If opt-in is correlated with productivity-related traits and only opt-ins are analyzed, the causal claim is not supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment is randomized (or opt-in is unrelated to productivity determinants) and a comparable control exists, the causal claim could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that allowing WFH increases productivity because the analysis conditions on who opted in; self-selection can explain the observed improvement.
gold_rationale: The evaluated sample is restricted to opt-ins, who may be more motivated or better suited for remote work. This selection bias means the observed pre/post change is not a valid estimate of the do(X) effect for employees in general.

scenario: A company compares projects completed by remote vs in-office employees. Overall, remote workers complete fewer projects. But within every department, remote workers complete more projects than in-office workers. Remote employees are concentrated in lower-baseline departments, while in-office employees are concentrated in higher-baseline departments.
claim: If we assign employees to work remotely, they will complete fewer projects than if they work in the office.
label: NO

Y.name: Number of projects completed in the review period

Z: Department (baseline project volume and remote-work prevalence)

causal_structure: Department (Z) affects both the likelihood of remote work (X) and baseline output (Y). Aggregating across Z reverses the within-department relationship.
key_insight: The pooled effect is misleading when group composition differs; stratifying by the confounder flips the sign.
hidden_timestamp: Are remote and in-office employees unevenly distributed across departments with different baseline project counts?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If department mix differs (as described), the aggregate comparison is confounded and the claim is not supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If remote and in-office employees are comparable within departments (or properly adjusted for department), the causal direction could be assessed more reliably.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude remote assignment reduces projects from the pooled data because department composition confounds the comparison and produces a Simpson’s reversal.
gold_rationale: Within each department remote workers outperform, but remote workers are concentrated in low-output departments. Department is a common cause of both assignment and output, so the aggregate association reverses and does not identify the do(X) effect.

scenario: A company estimates whether assigning employees to a time management workshop increases productivity. Analysts restrict the dataset to employees who improved their time tracking after the workshop and also adjust for the amount of time-tracking improvement when estimating the workshop’s effect.
claim: If we assign employees to the time management workshop, their overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

X.name: Assignment to the time management workshop

Y.name: Overall productivity in the following month

Z: Post-workshop time-tracking improvement (mediator)

causal_structure: Workshop assignment (X) affects time-tracking improvement (Z), which affects productivity (Y). Conditioning on Z (restricting to improvers and adjusting for improvement) biases the total effect estimate.
key_insight: You can’t estimate the total effect of X on Y while conditioning on a mediator caused by X.
hidden_timestamp: Did the analysis restrict to or adjust for time-tracking improvement measured after workshop assignment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis conditions on post-treatment improvement (as described), the causal claim about the total effect is not supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the effect is estimated using all assigned vs unassigned employees without conditioning on post-treatment mediators (or with a proper mediation analysis), the causal claim could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute productivity changes to the workshop when the analysis conditions on time-tracking improvement, which is itself caused by the workshop and lies on the causal pathway.
gold_rationale: Time-tracking improvement is post-treatment and plausibly mediates the workshop’s effect. Restricting/adjusting on it blocks part of the causal pathway and can introduce bias, so the described analysis does not justify the do(X) claim.

scenario: After introducing flexible work hours, pooled data show higher productivity among employees on flexible hours. But within each department, employees on fixed hours have higher productivity than those on flexible hours. Flexible hours were adopted more heavily in departments with higher baseline productivity.
claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Y.name: Employee productivity during the evaluation period

Z: Department (baseline productivity and adoption differences)

causal_structure: Department (Z) affects both flexible-hours adoption (X) and baseline productivity (Y), causing the pooled association to differ from within-department comparisons.
key_insight: The overall average can be driven by group mix rather than the within-group causal relationship.
hidden_timestamp: Were flexible hours adopted more in high-baseline departments, making the pooled comparison non-comparable?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If department mix drives the pooled difference (as described), the claim is not supported by the aggregate data.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If comparisons properly control for department (or assignment is randomized within department), the causal effect of flexible hours could be assessed.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude flexible hours raise productivity from the pooled comparison because department confounding produces a Simpson’s reversal.
gold_rationale: Within each department fixed-hours employees outperform, but flexible hours are concentrated in higher-baseline departments, inflating the pooled average. Department confounds assignment and outcome, so the do(X) effect is not identified by the aggregate association.

scenario: A company rewards teams for sending the highest number of emails each week. Email volume rises sharply, but project completion does not improve and managers observe duplicated work and worse coordination.
claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Email volume (proxy metric)
Gaming/low-value emailing and time diversion

causal_structure: Incentivizing a proxy (email count) changes behavior to inflate the proxy, which can decouple from or harm true output (Y).
key_insight: When a metric becomes the target, it stops being a reliable measure of the goal.
hidden_timestamp: Did real output (deliverables/projects) increase, or did only email volume increase after incentives were introduced?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the proxy is gameable and output does not improve (as described), the claim is invalid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the incentivized metric is tightly linked to real output and cannot be gamed (and output increases), the claim could be supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude productivity increased because rewarding email count encourages gaming; more emails can reflect low-value activity rather than increased real output.
gold_rationale: The incentive targets a proxy (email volume). The scenario reports higher email counts without higher deliverables and with worse coordination, consistent with Goodhart’s law; therefore the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: A company gives gift cards to employees who send the most emails each week. Email volume increases, but the company provides no evidence that concrete output improved and employees report spending time crafting unnecessary messages to compete for rewards.
claim: If we reward employees for sending more emails, overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

X.name: Rewards tied to high email volume

Z: Email volume (proxy metric)
Gaming/low-value emailing and time displacement

causal_structure: Targeting the proxy (email count) induces behavior that increases emails without necessarily increasing output, and may reduce output by consuming time.
key_insight: A proxy inflated by incentives is not evidence of improved true performance.
hidden_timestamp: Is there evidence that real output increased, or only that email counts increased under the incentive?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only email counts increase and behavior is gamed (as described), the claim is not supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If output metrics rise in tandem and the email metric is validated as non-gameable, the claim could be supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot infer a productivity gain from higher email volume because incentives can cause gaming; without evidence of improved deliverables, the causal claim does not follow.
gold_rationale: The scenario indicates the incentivized metric rises while true output is unverified and gaming is reported, which is a Goodhart trap. Therefore the causal claim is flawed.

scenario: A company analyzes only employees who enrolled in a voluntary wellness program. Within that volunteer group, employees assigned to take daily walks report higher job satisfaction. Enrollment tends to attract more health-conscious or motivated employees, which can also affect job satisfaction.
claim: If we assign employees to take daily walks, it will increase their job satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Voluntary wellness-program enrollment (selected sample)
Motivation/health-consciousness (pre-existing differences)

causal_structure: Restricting analysis to volunteers (Z) creates a non-representative sample correlated with traits that affect satisfaction (Y), so the do(X) effect is not identified for all employees.
key_insight: Conditioning on who enters the study (volunteers) can create or exaggerate apparent treatment benefits.
hidden_timestamp: Was the analysis conducted on all employees or only on those who voluntarily enrolled in the wellness program?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only volunteers are analyzed and volunteering is linked to satisfaction-related traits, the claim is not supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If employees are sampled/assigned independent of volunteering (or volunteering is irrelevant to satisfaction determinants), the causal effect could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude daily walks increase satisfaction because the evidence comes from a volunteer-only sample; selection into the program may explain the observed difference.
gold_rationale: Voluntary enrollment selects employees who may already differ in motivation/health orientation, which also affects satisfaction. This selection bias invalidates the causal inference about do(X) for the broader employee population.

scenario: A company launches a wellness program encouraging breaks and exercise. After a month, productivity is higher, and managers attribute the change to the program. But employees who are already feeling productive are more likely to join and keep participating, and participation may also affect productivity, creating a reinforcing cycle.
claim: If we assign employees to participate in the wellness program, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Baseline productivity/prior performance
Time-varying self-selection into continued participation

causal_structure: Productivity can increase later participation (Y→X over time) while participation can affect later productivity (X→Y), confounding attribution in a dynamic feedback loop.
key_insight: When X and Y influence each other across time, observed improvement cannot be attributed to X alone without breaking the loop.
hidden_timestamp: Does higher productivity also increase later participation (not just participation increasing productivity)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If productivity drives continued participation (feedback/self-selection), the observed association does not identify the causal effect of assigning participation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If participation is randomized/enforced over time (breaking Y→X), then the causal effect of participation on productivity could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude the program caused higher productivity because participation and productivity reinforce each other over time; without a design that breaks the feedback loop, the causal effect is not identified.
gold_rationale: The scenario describes time-varying feedback: productive employees are more likely to participate and keep participating, while participation may also affect productivity. This dynamic confounds causal attribution, so the claim is invalid as stated.

scenario: Pooled data suggest employees on flexible schedules have lower productivity than those on fixed schedules. But within every department, flexible schedules are associated with higher productivity. Flexible schedules were adopted more in lower-baseline departments, skewing the pooled comparison.
claim: If we assign employees to flexible work schedules, their productivity will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Department (baseline productivity and assignment patterns)

causal_structure: Department (Z) affects both schedule assignment (X) and baseline productivity (Y). Aggregation across unequal department mixes reverses the within-department direction.
key_insight: The sign of the pooled association can flip when confounder distributions differ across groups.
hidden_timestamp: Are flexible schedules disproportionately used in lower-baseline departments, making the pooled comparison misleading?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If department mix differs (as described), the pooled decrease is confounded and does not support the claim.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment is balanced within departments (or properly adjusted for Z), the causal direction could be assessed from within-department comparisons.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude flexibility decreases productivity from the aggregate data because department confounding produces a Simpson’s reversal.
gold_rationale: Within each department flexible schedules correlate with higher productivity, but flexible schedules are concentrated in low-output departments, pulling down the pooled average. This confounding reversal invalidates the claim.

scenario: A company rewards teams whose members send the most emails each week. Employees send many more emails, but deliverables do not improve and employees report sending extra messages mainly to win rewards rather than coordinate real work.
claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Email volume (proxy metric)
Communication overhead / gaming behavior

causal_structure: Targeting email volume increases the metric but can decouple it from true output and add overhead that harms productivity.
key_insight: More of a targeted proxy is not evidence of more of the goal.
hidden_timestamp: Did real output improve, or is the conclusion based only on increased email counts after incentives?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only email counts rise and output is unchanged (as described), the claim is unsupported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If output increases and the proxy is validated as non-gameable and tightly linked to output, the claim could be supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot infer productivity increased because the policy rewards a proxy that can be gamed; without output gains, higher email volume does not establish a causal benefit.
