gold_rationale: Email volume is a gameable proxy. The scenario reports increased emails without improved deliverables and with gaming/overhead, consistent with a Goodhart trap, so the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A company studies whether giving employees ergonomic chairs increases overall job satisfaction. After assigning some employees ergonomic chairs and others standard chairs, analysts compare satisfaction but adjust for 'comfort while sitting' measured after chair assignment.
claim: If we assign employees ergonomic chairs, their overall job satisfaction will increase.
label: NO

Z: Post-assignment sitting comfort (mediator)

causal_structure: Chair assignment (X) changes comfort (Z), which influences satisfaction (Y). Adjusting for Z blocks part of the causal pathway and biases the total effect.
key_insight: Adjusting for a mediator can erase or distort the very effect you want to estimate.
hidden_timestamp: Was 'comfort while sitting' measured after chair assignment and then controlled for in the analysis?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis adjusts for post-assignment comfort (as described), it cannot justify the total-effect claim about ergonomic chairs.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the total effect is estimated without conditioning on the mediator (or via a correct mediation analysis separating direct/indirect effects), the causal claim could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot support the total-effect claim because controlling for post-assignment comfort blocks the mechanism by which chairs affect satisfaction and yields a biased estimate.
gold_rationale: Comfort is downstream of chair assignment and plausibly mediates job satisfaction. Adjusting for it blocks part of the causal pathway and distorts the total effect, so the described analysis does not support the claim.

scenario: A manager observes that employees who receive extra training tend to have higher productivity scores. Historically, employees selected for extra training were those who already scored highly (or had improved) before the training decision.
claim: If we assign extra training to employees, their productivity scores will increase.
label: NO

Z: Prior performance / earlier productivity (used to select trainees)

causal_structure: Prior performance (Z) influences both selection into training (X) and later productivity scores (Y), creating an association that can be mistaken for X→Y.
key_insight: Training may be assigned because employees are already high performers, not because training causes high performance.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees chosen for extra training because they already had high (or improving) productivity scores before training?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If training is assigned based on prior performance (as described), the observed association does not support the causal claim.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If training is assigned independently of prior performance (e.g., randomized) with a valid comparison group, the causal effect could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude training causes higher productivity scores because employees were selected for training based on prior high performance, which can explain the observed pattern.
gold_rationale: The relationship is driven by reactive assignment: high performers are more likely to receive training. Prior performance is a common cause of both training and later scores, so the do(X) effect is not identified from this observation.

scenario: A company offers a free online productivity course to employees with below-average performance. An internal report evaluates effectiveness but includes only employees who improved after taking the course and excludes those who did not improve. The report concludes the course causes better performance.
claim: If we assign employees to take the online productivity course, their performance will improve.
label: NO

X.name: Assignment to the online productivity course

Z: Being included in the report (only improvers included)
Post-course improvement criterion used for inclusion

causal_structure: Inclusion (Z) is determined by improvement/outcome, so restricting to Z=1 guarantees apparent success and breaks causal inference about X→Y.
key_insight: Selecting cases based on success makes the intervention look effective even if it isn’t.
hidden_timestamp: Did the evaluation exclude employees who did not improve after the course and only report on improvers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only improvers are included (as described), the claim is invalid because the positive result is an artifact of selection.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all assigned employees are included (improvers and non-improvers) and compared to a control/baseline, the causal effect could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot claim the course causes improvement when the report includes only employees who improved; that outcome-based selection guarantees a positive-looking result.
gold_rationale: The report conditions on improvement by excluding non-improvers, which is a selection trap. This invalidates causal inference: the apparent effect is induced by filtering on the outcome rather than caused by the course.

scenario: A company evaluates flexible work hours by analyzing only employees who opted in to flexible hours and excluding employees who left the company before or shortly after the policy was introduced. They compare productivity among the remaining employees.
claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Opt-in choice (self-selection into flexible hours)
Remaining employed/observed after the policy (attrition/retention)

causal_structure: Productivity-related traits can affect opt-in, and attrition can depend on productivity or schedule fit; restricting to observed survivors biases the estimated do(X) effect.
key_insight: Combining opt-in and excluding leavers can make an intervention look beneficial by selecting a favorable subset.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees randomly assigned and measured regardless of opt-in/attrition, or were opt-ins and survivors selectively analyzed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If opt-in and attrition depend on productivity determinants (as described), the causal claim is not supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment is randomized (or properly adjusted) and productivity is measured for all employees regardless of attrition (intention-to-treat), the causal effect could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude flexible hours increase productivity because the analysis is restricted to opt-ins and employees who stayed long enough to be observed; survivorship and self-selection can explain the observed differences.
gold_rationale: The comparison conditions on who opted in and who remained employed/observed. These selection processes are plausibly related to productivity and schedule fit, so the observed association is biased and does not identify the do(X) effect.

scenario: A manager notices employees who take public transportation tend to arrive earlier than those who drive. The company considers forcing everyone to use public transportation. However, employees who live closer to the office are more likely to use public transportation and are also more likely to arrive earlier regardless of commute method.
claim: If we assign all employees to use public transportation, they will arrive at work earlier.
label: NO

Z: Distance from home to office

causal_structure: Distance (Z) affects both commute mode (X) and arrival time (Y), creating a backdoor path X←Z→Y that biases the inferred do(X) effect.
key_insight: Correlation between transit use and earliness can be explained by distance, not by transit causing earlier arrival.
hidden_timestamp: Do transit users arrive earlier even when comparing employees with the same commute distance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If distance differs between transit users and drivers (as described), the causal claim is not supported because Z confounds X and Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If distance (and closely related commute constraints) is controlled for or commute mode is randomized, the causal effect of transit on arrival time could be evaluated.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude public transportation causes earlier arrival because distance to the office affects both commute choice and arrival time; without controlling for distance or randomizing commute mode, the do(X) effect is not identified.
gold_rationale: Distance is a common cause of both using transit and arriving earlier. The observed association can be entirely due to confounding, so the intervention claim is invalid as stated.

scenario: A workplace introduces a flexible schedule policy that lets employees choose their start and end times. Afterward, employees who start later report higher job satisfaction than employees who start earlier. Management concludes that assigning later start times will increase job satisfaction for all employees.
claim: If we assign employees to later start times, their job satisfaction will increase.
label: NO

Z: Preference/need for later start time (e.g., chronotype, caregiving constraints)
Baseline job satisfaction / workplace fit (pre-policy)

causal_structure: Employees choose start times under the policy; baseline satisfaction/fit and personal constraints (Z) influence both chosen start time (X) and reported satisfaction (Y). In addition, prior satisfaction can influence which schedule people select, so X is endogenous.
key_insight: When people self-select the “treatment,” the observed association can reflect reverse direction or selection, not do(X).
hidden_timestamp: Were later start times assigned exogenously (randomly/by rule) rather than chosen by employees based on preferences or satisfaction?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If later vs earlier start times were assigned by a policy rule unrelated to baseline satisfaction/preferences (or randomized) and satisfaction was measured afterward, the claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If employees chose their start times and that choice was related to baseline satisfaction or constraints, the observed difference does not justify the causal claim.

wise_refusal: We cannot endorse the causal claim because start times are self-chosen under the flexible policy. Employees’ preferences/constraints and prior satisfaction can drive both the chosen start time and later reported satisfaction, so the association does not identify the effect of assigning later starts.
gold_rationale: Because X is not exogenously assigned, later starters may differ systematically (or may choose later starts because they are already more satisfied/better matched), producing an apparent X–Y relationship without a causal effect of assignment.

scenario: A company evaluates whether assigning employees to a time management workshop (X) increases overall productivity (Y). In the analysis, they adjust for the number of tasks completed immediately after the workshop, which is itself affected by attending the workshop, and then compare productivity between assigned vs not assigned employees while controlling for this post-workshop task completion.
claim: If we assign employees to the time management workshop, their overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Tasks completed immediately after the workshop

causal_structure: Workshop assignment (X) can increase immediate task completion (Z), which can in turn influence overall productivity (Y). Conditioning on Z (a downstream mediator) blocks part of the causal pathway and can bias/attenuate the total effect estimate.
key_insight: Don’t control for variables caused by the treatment when estimating the total effect of do(X).
hidden_timestamp: Is the adjusted variable (tasks completed immediately after the workshop) measured after assignment and caused by the workshop?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis compares assigned vs not assigned employees without conditioning on post-treatment variables (or uses an explicit mediation framework targeting a direct effect), the causal claim could be evaluated appropriately.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis controls for post-workshop task completion as described, it does not identify the total effect of assignment on productivity.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim based on this analysis because it conditions on a post-treatment mediator (tasks completed immediately after the workshop). That adjustment blocks part of the pathway from workshop assignment to productivity and can produce a misleading estimate of the total effect.
gold_rationale: Adjusting for Z (a mediator caused by X) prevents estimation of the total causal effect of assignment on productivity; the reported comparison is therefore not valid evidence for the claim as stated.

scenario: A company analyzes productivity after introducing flexible work hours. Overall, employees who switch to flexible hours appear more productive than those who keep fixed hours. However, when stratifying by department, every department shows that switching to flexible hours reduces productivity compared to staying fixed. Management still concludes that assigning flexible hours increases productivity.
claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Department

causal_structure: Department (Z) affects both the prevalence of switching to flexible hours (X) and baseline productivity (Y). Aggregation across departments reverses the within-department relationship, making the overall association misleading for do(X).
key_insight: If every subgroup contradicts the aggregate, the aggregate is not a valid basis for an intervention claim.
hidden_timestamp: Within each department, does switching to flexible hours increase or decrease productivity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we estimate the effect within departments (or properly adjust for department mix), the evidence indicates flexible hours reduce productivity, contradicting the claim.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we rely only on the aggregate comparison without accounting for department, the positive trend can be a Simpson’s paradox artifact and does not support the causal claim.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the data exhibit Simpson’s paradox: the aggregate association is positive, but within every department the association is negative. For an intervention claim, the within-stratum or properly adjusted comparisons are the relevant ones, and they contradict the claim.
gold_rationale: Because the direction reverses in every department, the overall positive association is an aggregation artifact driven by department mix; it does not identify a positive causal effect of assigning flexible hours.

scenario: A company introduces an employee wellness program and tracks sick days. After seeing a reduction in sick days, management expands the program. Over time, employees adapt to the policy—some change how they report sick days or take leave differently because the program changes incentives and norms. The policy and employee behavior influence each other over time.
claim: If we expand the wellness program, employees will consistently take fewer sick days.
label: NO

Z: Changing reporting norms/incentives induced by the program
Management responds to prior sick-day trends when deciding expansions

causal_structure: Program expansion (X) influences sick-day behavior/reporting (Y) through changing incentives/norms (Z), but observed outcomes (Y) also influence future expansions (X). This creates a feedback loop and non-stationary behavior.
key_insight: With feedback and adaptation, early effects don’t justify a stable “consistently” claim under repeated policy changes.
hidden_timestamp: Does management adjust program expansion in response to earlier sick-day outcomes, and do employees change reporting/leave behavior because the program changes incentives over time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If expansion were a one-time exogenous change held fixed and reporting rules/incentives remained stable, a consistent direction could be evaluated with standard causal analysis.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If employees adapt and management escalates the program in response to outcomes (as described), the claim of consistently fewer sick days is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the scenario describes a feedback system: management expands the program in response to observed sick days, and employees change reporting/leave behavior in response to the program. That makes the effect time-varying and undermines the claim that expansion will consistently reduce sick days.
gold_rationale: Because X and Y co-evolve through policy response and behavioral adaptation, the setting is not a one-way intervention with a stable effect; the stronger claim of consistent reductions is unjustified.

scenario: A company rewards teams solely based on the number of emails sent per week. After implementing the policy, email volume rises sharply, but project completion rates and meaningful collaboration do not improve.
claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Email count as a proxy metric for productivity

causal_structure: The policy directly targets a proxy measure (Z = email count), allowing teams to increase Z without improving the true outcome Y. Once optimized, Z no longer reliably measures Y.
key_insight: When the metric becomes the target, it stops being a good measure of what you care about.
hidden_timestamp: Is the rewarded metric (email count) a valid measure of true productivity after it becomes the explicit target?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If incentives targeted validated productivity outcomes (e.g., completed milestones, quality measures) rather than a proxy, increased incentives could plausibly improve productivity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If incentives target email volume as the proxy (as described), the metric can be inflated without improving true productivity, so the claim is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the policy targets a proxy (email volume) rather than productivity itself. Teams can increase email counts by sending redundant or low-value messages, so higher email volume does not imply higher productivity—this is Goodhart’s Law.
gold_rationale: Email count is a manipulable proxy; when incentivized, it can rise while true productivity does not, so the intervention claim fails.

scenario: A company introduces a work-from-home option and analyzes only the productivity of employees who voluntarily choose to work from home. These volunteers appear more productive than employees who remain in the office. The company concludes that assigning anyone to work from home will increase productivity.
claim: If we assign employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Voluntary opt-in / suitability for remote work (role fit, home setup, motivation)

causal_structure: Employees self-select into WFH (Z) based on traits linked to productivity. Comparing volunteers to non-volunteers does not identify the effect of assigning WFH to everyone.
key_insight: Opt-in evidence doesn’t generalize to do(X) for the full population.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees randomly assigned to WFH vs office, or were the results based only on volunteers who chose WFH?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees were randomly assigned to WFH vs office (or selection was appropriately adjusted) and outcomes were measured for all, the claim could be evaluated causally.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis includes only volunteers who choose WFH (as described), selection bias can explain the difference, so the claim is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the causal claim because the evidence comes from an opt-in subgroup. Employees who choose WFH may be more motivated or better suited for remote work, which can increase productivity regardless of assignment, so the observed association does not identify do(X).
gold_rationale: Restricting analysis to volunteers induces selection bias; the apparent productivity advantage may reflect who opts in rather than the effect of assignment.

scenario: A company rewards teams based on the number of emails sent each week. Teams respond by sending more emails, including redundant messages, to meet the target. Email volume increases sharply, but project completion and meaningful collaboration do not improve.
claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Email count used as a target metric (proxy)

causal_structure: X directly increases the proxy Z (email count), but Z is no longer a reliable indicator of Y once it is rewarded; employees can inflate Z without improving Y.
key_insight: A proxy metric rising under incentives is not evidence the real objective improved.
hidden_timestamp: After email count becomes the rewarded target, does it still reflect true productivity rather than metric-gaming?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If incentives were aligned to true productivity outputs (e.g., milestone completion, quality measures), incentivizing effort could plausibly increase productivity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If incentives target email volume (as described), the proxy can be gamed and does not support the causal claim.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because this is Goodhart’s Law: once email volume is rewarded, employees can inflate the metric with low-value messages while true productivity stays flat, so increasing emails does not imply do(X) increases Y.
gold_rationale: The incentivized proxy increases without improvements in project completion or collaboration, showing metric-gaming rather than a causal productivity gain.

scenario: Researchers study whether assigning employees to regular group exercise sessions (X) increases job satisfaction (Y). In the analysis, they adjust for employees’ energy levels measured after the exercise sessions.
claim: If we assign employees to regular group exercise sessions, their overall job satisfaction will increase.
label: NO

Z: Post-exercise energy level

causal_structure: Exercise assignment (X) can increase energy (Z), which can affect job satisfaction (Y). Adjusting for Z (a mediator) distorts the total-effect estimate of X on Y.
key_insight: Controlling for a post-treatment mediator can bias the estimated effect of assignment.
hidden_timestamp: Is energy level measured after the exercise intervention and plausibly caused by assignment to exercise?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If satisfaction were compared between assigned vs not assigned employees without conditioning on post-exercise energy (or using a mediation method targeting a direct effect), the causal effect could be assessed properly.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis adjusts for post-exercise energy as described, it does not identify the total effect of assignment on satisfaction.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim as supported by this analysis because it adjusts for a post-treatment mediator (energy after exercise). That conditioning blocks part of the pathway from exercise to satisfaction and can bias the estimate of the total effect of assignment.
gold_rationale: Energy is downstream of assignment and can mediate the effect on satisfaction; conditioning on it invalidates a total-effect intervention claim under the stated analysis.

scenario: A workplace wellness program encourages employees to attend lunchtime yoga. Observationally, attendees report lower stress than non-attendees. However, those who choose to attend yoga are often already engaged in other stress-reducing habits outside work.
claim: If we assign employees to attend lunchtime yoga classes, their stress levels will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Personal interest in wellness
Pre-existing stress-management habits outside work

causal_structure: Wellness orientation and pre-existing habits (Z) influence both yoga attendance (X) and stress outcomes (Y). Without blocking backdoor paths, the association does not identify do(X).
key_insight: Voluntary participation can be confounded by baseline differences that also affect outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees assigned to yoga, or did they self-select into yoga based on pre-existing wellness/stress-management habits?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees were randomly assigned to yoga vs not (or baseline wellness/stress habits were adequately controlled), the causal claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If attendance is voluntary and baseline wellness habits drive both yoga participation and lower stress (as described), the causal claim is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the intervention claim from this observational comparison because yoga attendees differ in baseline wellness habits that also reduce stress. Without exogenous assignment or sufficient adjustment for those confounders, the association does not justify do(X) reducing Y.
gold_rationale: Self-selected yoga attendance is confounded by pre-existing wellness habits, so the observed lower stress may reflect who attends rather than the effect of assignment.

scenario: A company reviews productivity data and finds that overall, employees who attend more training sessions tend to have lower annual performance scores. But when looking separately at junior and senior employees, attending more training is associated with higher performance in both groups. The overall negative association appears only after aggregating across seniority.
claim: If we assign employees to attend more training sessions, their annual performance scores will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Employee seniority (junior vs senior)

causal_structure: Seniority (Z) affects baseline performance and training attendance patterns. Aggregating across Z reverses the within-group relationship, producing a misleading overall association for do(X).
key_insight: If the aggregate says one thing but every subgroup says the opposite, the aggregate is misleading for interventions.
hidden_timestamp: Within each seniority group (junior and senior), is more training associated with higher or lower performance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we analyze within seniority groups (or adjust for seniority), the relationship is positive in both groups, contradicting the claim.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we rely only on the aggregated association across seniority, Simpson’s paradox can flip the direction and does not support the causal claim.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the pattern matches Simpson’s paradox: the aggregate association is negative, but within both junior and senior groups more training is associated with higher performance. An intervention claim must be based on stratified/adjusted comparisons, which contradict the claim here.
gold_rationale: The overall negative association is an artifact of mixing junior and senior employees; within each group training correlates with higher performance, so the claim that assigning more training decreases performance is flawed.

scenario: A company analyzes only employees who joined a voluntary wellness program and completed all required check-ins. Among these compliant participants, those assigned to daily meditation report higher job satisfaction than those not assigned meditation. The analysis excludes dropouts and anyone who missed check-ins.
claim: If we assign employees to daily meditation sessions, it will increase their job satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Program compliance/completion (completed all check-ins)

causal_structure: Compliance/completion (Z) is affected by assignment (X) and by unmeasured traits (e.g., motivation, baseline satisfaction) that also influence Y. Conditioning on Z induces collider/selection bias and breaks causal inference.
key_insight: Analyzing only completers breaks randomization and can create spurious treatment effects.
hidden_timestamp: Does the analysis include all assigned employees, or only those who completed all program check-ins (compliers/completers)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If outcomes are analyzed using intention-to-treat (all assigned employees regardless of compliance), the causal effect of assignment could be assessed without conditioning on compliance.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis restricts to completers/compliers (as described), conditioning on compliance can induce collider bias, so the claim is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the analysis conditions on compliance (completing all check-ins). Compliance is influenced by assignment and by unmeasured traits that also affect job satisfaction, so restricting to completers can create a biased, non-causal comparison.
gold_rationale: Selecting only completers conditions on a post-intervention collider/selection variable, which can induce spurious differences between assigned groups; therefore the intervention claim is not supported.

scenario: A company wants to know whether assigning employees to a time management workshop (X) increases their overall productivity one month later (Y). In their analysis, they control for the number of workshop exercises/tasks employees completed during the workshop sessions, even though completing those exercises is directly caused by being assigned/attending the workshop.
claim: If we assign employees to the time management workshop, their overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Number of workshop exercises/tasks completed during the workshop

causal_structure: Assignment to the workshop (X) influences engagement/completion of workshop tasks (Z), which may affect later productivity (Y). Controlling for Z removes part of the pathway from X to Y and can bias the total-effect estimate.
key_insight: Controlling for a downstream mediator undermines estimation of the total effect of assignment.
hidden_timestamp: Is the controlled variable (tasks completed during the workshop) caused by assignment to the workshop and measured after assignment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the effect is estimated without conditioning on post-assignment mediators (or with a proper mediation framework targeting a direct effect), the claim could be evaluated appropriately.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis controls for tasks completed during the workshop as described, it does not identify the total effect of assignment on later productivity.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the analysis controls for workshop tasks completed, which is a post-assignment mediator. Conditioning on this variable blocks part of the causal pathway from assignment to productivity and can bias the total-effect estimate.
gold_rationale: Tasks completed during the workshop are downstream of assignment and plausibly mediate productivity gains; adjusting for them invalidates a total-effect intervention inference under the stated analysis.

scenario: A company uses a productivity-tracking app. After noticing a drop in productivity, management increases the frequency of reminder notifications to use the app. Employees feel micromanaged and begin ignoring the reminders or finding ways to avoid logging work, which further reduces measured productivity over time. Management continues escalating reminders in response to the continued productivity decline.
claim: If we increase the frequency of productivity app reminders, employee productivity will improve.
label: NO

Y.name: Employee productivity (measured by app logs and/or output)

Z: Employee avoidance/resistance behavior toward the app
Management increases reminders in response to prior productivity drops

causal_structure: Productivity declines (Y) trigger increases in reminders (X), and reminders increase avoidance (Z) that further reduces measured productivity (Y). This creates a Y→X→Y feedback loop with adaptation.
key_insight: When the “treatment” responds to the outcome, you can’t read a stable causal effect off the observed dynamics.
hidden_timestamp: Does measured productivity affect future reminder frequency, and do employees adapt their logging behavior in response to reminders?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If reminder frequency were set exogenously and held fixed (no Y→X escalation) and productivity were measured objectively without avoidable logging, the effect could be assessed causally.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If reminders are increased in response to productivity drops and employees adapt by avoiding logging (as described), the claim that more reminders improves productivity is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the scenario describes a feedback loop: productivity drops cause management to increase reminders, and increased reminders provoke avoidance that lowers measured productivity further. With this adaptation and Y→X response, a simple one-way causal claim is not identified.
gold_rationale: Since reminder frequency is adjusted based on prior productivity and employees change behavior in response, the system is a feedback loop and does not support the claim that increasing reminders causally improves productivity.

scenario: A company introduces an employee wellness program and tracks participation and health metrics over several months. As participation rises early on, average health metrics improve. Management concludes that continually increasing participation will keep improving health outcomes, without considering diminishing returns or behavioral adaptation (e.g., healthier employees disengaging or the remaining nonparticipants being harder to help).
claim: If we increase participation in the wellness program, employee health outcomes will keep improving.
label: NO

X.name: Participation rate in the wellness program

Y.name: Average employee health outcomes over time

Z: Changing composition of marginal participants (late recruits differ from early adopters)
Saturation/diminishing returns and engagement adaptation over time

causal_structure: Early adopters may be easier to help; as participation expands, marginal participants can be less responsive and engagement can change, so the mechanism linking higher participation to better outcomes is not stable or monotone.
key_insight: Early gains don’t justify “it will keep improving” without a mechanism ruling out saturation and changing marginal effects.
hidden_timestamp: As participation expands, do marginal new participants remain equally responsive and engaged, or do responsiveness and engagement change (saturation/adaptation)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If each marginal increase in participation brought similarly responsive employees with sustained engagement and no saturation, increased participation could continue improving average outcomes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If later recruits are less responsive or engagement/adaptation causes diminishing returns (as described), the claim that outcomes will keep improving is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the stronger claim that increasing participation will keep improving outcomes because the scenario provides no stable mechanism ensuring constant marginal benefits. Composition changes and diminishing returns/adaptation can break the monotone extrapolation.
gold_rationale: Observed early improvements do not establish indefinite monotone improvement: later participants can differ and saturation/adaptation can weaken the mechanism, so the claim is not justified.

scenario: A workplace wellness program wants to estimate the effect of assigning employees to a daily meditation session (X) on their stress level at the end of the month (Y). In the analysis, they statistically control for the number of relaxation breaks employees take during the day, even though taking more relaxation breaks is influenced by being assigned to meditation.
claim: If we assign employees to daily meditation sessions, it will reduce their overall stress levels compared to not assigning meditation.
label: NO

Y.name: Overall stress level at month end

Z: Number of relaxation breaks taken during the day

causal_structure: Meditation assignment (X) can increase relaxation breaks (Z), which can reduce stress (Y). Controlling for Z blocks part of the pathway and biases the estimated total effect of X on Y.
key_insight: If you control for the mechanism (a mediator), you can’t claim the total treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Is the controlled variable (relaxation breaks) measured after assignment and influenced by the meditation assignment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis estimates the intention-to-treat effect without conditioning on post-assignment behaviors like breaks (or targets a direct effect with appropriate mediation methods), the causal effect could be assessed.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis controls for relaxation breaks as described, it does not identify the total effect of assigning meditation on stress.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the analysis controls for relaxation breaks, which are a post-assignment mediator—one way meditation could reduce stress is by increasing breaks. Conditioning on this mediator blocks part of the causal pathway, so the analysis does not support the total-effect claim.
gold_rationale: Relaxation breaks are downstream of assignment and can affect stress; conditioning on them biases the total-effect estimate, so the intervention claim is not supported as stated.

scenario: A company wants to know if assigning employees to work from home (X) increases productivity (Y). They run an analysis only on employees who (i) complied with the work-from-home assignment and (ii) submitted productivity reports, excluding noncompliers and non-responders.
claim: If we assign employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Compliance with assignment (actually worked from home)
Submitting a productivity report (observed outcome)

causal_structure: Compliance/response (Z) are post-assignment variables influenced by X and by unmeasured traits related to productivity (e.g., motivation, organization, workload). Conditioning on Z induces selection/collider bias.
key_insight: Restricting to compliers/reporters can create a spurious treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Does the analysis include all assigned employees, or only those who complied and submitted reports (a post-assignment subset)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the company analyzes outcomes for all employees as assigned (intention-to-treat) and handles missingness appropriately, the causal effect could be assessed without conditioning on post-assignment selection.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis restricts to compliers and report-submitters (as described), conditioning on post-assignment selection can bias the effect, so the claim is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because analyzing only employees who complied and submitted reports conditions on post-assignment selection. Those behaviors can depend on assignment and on productivity-related traits, creating collider/selection bias and a non-causal comparison.
gold_rationale: Because the analysis conditions on post-treatment compliance/response, it can induce selection bias and does not identify the causal effect of assignment on productivity.

scenario: A company evaluates a voluntary wellness program. In the analysis, they include only employees who completed the program (and remained compliant through the end). Within this selected group, those assigned to take daily walks (X) show lower stress scores (Y) than others.
claim: If we assign employees to take daily walks, their stress levels will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Program completion/continued compliance (being included in the analysis)

causal_structure: Completion/compliance (Z) is affected by assignment and by unmeasured stress-related traits (motivation, baseline stress, time availability). Conditioning on Z selects a biased subgroup and can create spurious differences in stress.
key_insight: Only analyzing completers can manufacture a treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Are only employees who completed the program included in the comparison (excluding dropouts/noncompliers)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If stress is compared for all employees as assigned (intention-to-treat), including dropouts, the causal effect could be assessed without conditioning on completion.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis includes only compliant completers (as described), conditioning on completion can induce selection/collider bias, so the claim is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the analysis conditions on program completion/compliance, a post-assignment selection variable influenced by both assignment and stress-related traits. Restricting to completers can create a biased, non-causal comparison.
gold_rationale: Excluding noncompleters conditions on a post-treatment collider/selection process; the observed lower stress among completers does not identify the causal effect of assigning walks.

scenario: A company evaluates a remote work program by analyzing only employees who voluntarily switched to remote work and remained in the program for at least six months. Employees who returned to the office or left earlier are excluded. Productivity is compared using only this retained subgroup.
claim: If we assign employees to work remotely, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Staying in the remote program for at least 6 months (retention)

causal_structure: Retention (Z) is a post-intervention filter influenced by remote-work assignment and by how well remote work fits the employee (which also affects productivity). Restricting to Z=1 removes failures/early exits and biases the observed X–Y relationship.
key_insight: If you only observe “stayers,” you overestimate benefits by dropping the failures.
hidden_timestamp: Is the productivity analysis restricted to employees who stayed remote for ≥6 months (excluding early exits/returns)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If productivity is analyzed for all eligible/assigned employees (including those who returned early), using intention-to-treat, the causal effect could be assessed without survivorship bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis only includes employees who stayed remote for ≥6 months, the sample is selected by survivorship and does not support the causal claim.

wise_refusal: We cannot accept the claim because the analysis conditions on staying in the remote program for six months, which is a post-intervention survivorship filter. Employees for whom remote work is unproductive or unsuitable are more likely to exit early, so analyzing only “stayers” biases the comparison and does not identify the effect of assignment for all employees.
gold_rationale: Restricting to retained remote workers excludes those who failed or left early, inducing survivorship bias; therefore the observed productivity difference does not justify the causal claim.

scenario: A company compares productivity between employees who worked from home and those who did not, but only among employees who complied with the work-from-home assignment. Noncompliers are excluded from the analysis. The company then concludes assignment increases productivity.
claim: If we assign employees to work from home, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Compliance with assignment (actually worked from home after being assigned)
Motivation / role suitability affecting both compliance and productivity

causal_structure: Assignment (X) affects compliance (Z). Motivation/role-suitability affects both compliance (Z) and productivity (Y). Conditioning on Z (an inclusion/analysis restriction) opens a non-causal path between X and Y.
key_insight: Analyzing only compliers conditions on a post-assignment selection variable, inducing collider/selection bias that can create a spurious productivity effect.
hidden_timestamp: Is the company restricting the analysis to a post-assignment subgroup defined by compliance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If productivity were compared by intention-to-treat (all assigned vs not assigned, regardless of compliance), the causal effect of assignment could be evaluated without conditioning on compliance.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis includes only compliers, the observed difference can be driven by selection/collider bias (e.g., motivation influences both compliance and productivity), so the causal claim is not justified.

wise_refusal: No. The analysis excludes noncompliers, which conditions on a post-assignment selection variable (compliance). Compliance can depend on assignment and on productivity-related traits (like motivation or job fit), creating collider/selection bias. The resulting productivity difference may be selection-driven rather than caused by assignment.
gold_rationale: Because the estimate is computed only among compliers (a post-treatment-selected subset), it does not identify the causal effect of assignment to work from home on productivity.

scenario: A company trials work-from-home. After a trial period, only employees who chose to continue working from home are surveyed, and those who returned to the office are excluded. The analysis compares reported productivity of this selected ‘continued WFH’ group to the office group.
claim: If we assign employees to work from home, their productivity will increase compared to office workers.
label: NO

Z: Post-trial continuation (staying WFH vs returning to office)
WFH fit / baseline performance influencing who continues and reported productivity

causal_structure: Assignment/offer (X) influences who continues WFH (Z). Fit/performance affects both Z and Y. Comparing only the ‘continued WFH’ group conditions on Z, yielding survivorship/self-selection bias.
key_insight: Defining the treated group by who stays in the program after exposure removes the people for whom WFH worked poorly, exaggerating the apparent benefit.
hidden_timestamp: Is the WFH group defined using a post-trial decision (continued WFH) rather than the original assignment/offer?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If outcomes were analyzed for everyone originally offered/assigned WFH (including those who returned), the causal effect of the offer/assignment could be assessed without post-selection.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only those who chose to continue WFH are analyzed, the observed productivity difference can be selection-driven (survivorship/self-selection) rather than caused by assignment.

wise_refusal: No. The analysis defines the WFH group based on who continued after a trial, which is post-intervention selection. People who found WFH unproductive are more likely to return to office and be excluded, so the remaining WFH sample is not comparable and can make WFH look better even without a true causal effect.
gold_rationale: Because treatment status is defined by post-trial continuation, the comparison is biased by survivorship/self-selection and cannot justify the causal claim about assignment.

scenario: A company compares productivity after implementing flexible work schedules. In the overall aggregate, employees on flexible schedules have higher average productivity than employees on fixed schedules. However, when broken down by department, in every department employees on fixed schedules outperform those on flexible schedules. Departments differ in baseline productivity and in how many employees use flexible schedules.
claim: If we assign employees to flexible work schedules, their productivity will increase compared to fixed schedules.
label: NO

Z: Department (baseline productivity differences)
Department-level adoption/assignment rates for flexible schedules

causal_structure: Department (Z) influences both who gets flexible schedules (X) and baseline productivity (Y). Aggregate comparisons differ from within-department comparisons, producing Simpson’s paradox.
key_insight: The aggregate pattern is misleading; within every department, flexible schedules are worse than fixed schedules, contradicting the causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: What happens to the X–Y comparison when you compare within each department instead of aggregating across departments?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the effect were evaluated within departments (or properly adjusted for department) and those within-department effects were positive, the claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Given that within every department fixed schedules outperform flexible schedules, the causal claim that flexible schedules increase productivity is not supported; the aggregate is a Simpson’s paradox artifact.

wise_refusal: No. This is Simpson’s paradox: the overall average suggests flexible schedules help, but within each department the opposite holds. Department is a common cause of schedule assignment and productivity, so the aggregate comparison is confounded and does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: Because the within-department comparisons reverse the aggregate association, department composition/confounding drives the aggregate result and invalidates the claim.

scenario: A company evaluates a new remote-work program but analyzes only employees who volunteered for the program and completed a satisfaction survey at the end. The company reports higher job satisfaction among those assigned to remote work than those assigned to in-office work, but only within the survey-completer subset.
claim: If we assign employees to remote work, their job satisfaction will increase compared to in-office assignment.
label: NO

Z: Volunteering/participation eligibility (selected into program)
Survey completion / responding at endline
Motivation/satisfaction-related traits affecting both response and satisfaction

causal_structure: Assignment (X) can affect survey completion/response. Satisfaction-related traits can also affect response. Conditioning on being observed/responding (and volunteering) yields selection/collider bias.
key_insight: Restricting to volunteers who complete a survey can create non-comparable groups; differences may reflect who is observed rather than the causal effect of assignment.
hidden_timestamp: Is job satisfaction compared only among a post-assignment selected subset (volunteers who completed the survey)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If satisfaction were measured for nearly all assigned employees (or missingness were handled with a valid design) without conditioning on response, the effect of assignment could be evaluated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis conditions on volunteering and survey completion, the observed difference can be selection/collider bias and does not justify the causal claim.

wise_refusal: No. The comparison is restricted to employees who volunteered and completed the survey, which is a selected subset. Survey completion can depend on assignment and on satisfaction-related factors, so conditioning on it can induce bias and make remote work appear to affect satisfaction even if it does not.
gold_rationale: Because the estimate is computed only among volunteers/survey-completers, selection/collider bias can drive the observed difference and the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: A company wants to estimate whether assigning employees to flexible work hours increases job satisfaction. Employees are assigned to either a flexible schedule or a standard schedule. After the policy starts, the company surveys employees about (1) work–life balance and (2) job satisfaction. In its regression, the company controls for the post-policy work–life balance score when estimating the effect of flexible-hours assignment on job satisfaction.
claim: If we assign employees to flexible work hours, their job satisfaction will increase.
label: NO

Z: Work–life balance score measured after the policy starts (post-treatment mediator)

causal_structure: Assignment (X) affects work–life balance (Z), which affects job satisfaction (Y). Conditioning on Z blocks part of the causal pathway and can bias the total effect estimate.
key_insight: Controlling for a post-treatment mediator removes part of the policy’s effect and can invalidate a claim about the total effect of assignment on satisfaction.
hidden_timestamp: Is work–life balance measured after the flexible-hours assignment begins (i.e., downstream of X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the goal is the total effect of assignment on satisfaction, the analysis should not control for post-treatment work–life balance; without that adjustment, the total effect could be evaluated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the regression controls for post-policy work–life balance, the estimate does not support a total-effect claim because it conditions on a mediator and can be biased.

wise_refusal: No. The analysis adjusts for work–life balance measured after assignment, which is on the causal path from flexible hours to satisfaction. Conditioning on it blocks part of the effect and can distort the estimate, so the regression result does not justify the claim about assignment increasing satisfaction.
gold_rationale: Because the model controls for a post-treatment mediator, it cannot support the total causal claim that assigning flexible hours increases job satisfaction.

scenario: A company wants to know whether assigning employees to remote work would increase productivity. Instead of randomly assigning, the company analyzes only employees who actually participate in the remote-work program and excludes employees who declined or were ineligible. The analysis reports that this included (remote) subset has higher productivity than the excluded employees.
claim: If we assign employees to remote work, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Selection into program participation / eligibility
Baseline motivation / job suitability for remote work

causal_structure: Participation/eligibility selects who appears in the remote group. Motivation/job fit affects both participation (and remote work) and productivity, so comparing participants vs non-participants conflates selection with treatment effect.
key_insight: Comparing only participants to non-participants mixes self-selection/eligibility with the effect of assignment and cannot identify the causal effect of assigning remote work broadly.
hidden_timestamp: Is the analysis restricted to employees who chose/qualified to participate (a selected subset), rather than all employees who would be assigned?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees were randomly assigned (or assigned by an exogenous rule) and outcomes were measured for everyone regardless of participation, the effect of assignment could be estimated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis includes only participants/eligible employees, the productivity gap can reflect selection (motivation/job fit) rather than the causal effect of assignment.

wise_refusal: No. The analysis only includes employees who participated or were eligible, and those employees can differ systematically in motivation and job fit. The higher productivity among participants may reflect selection into the program rather than the causal effect of assigning remote work.
gold_rationale: Because the comparison is made on a selected subset (participants/eligible), selection factors correlated with productivity can explain the difference, so the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: A company evaluates whether assigning employees to flexible work schedules affects productivity. Across the whole company, employees with flexible schedules appear to have lower productivity than those with fixed schedules. But when the company compares employees within each department, flexible-schedule employees have higher productivity than fixed-schedule peers in every department. Departments differ in both (a) how often flexible schedules are granted and (b) baseline productivity levels.
claim: If we assign employees to flexible work schedules, their productivity will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Department (baseline productivity differences)
Department-level flexibility granting rates

causal_structure: Department (Z) affects both schedule assignment (X) and productivity (Y). Aggregating across departments yields a misleading negative association that reverses within each department.
key_insight: The aggregate negative association is not causal; within every department flexible schedules are associated with higher productivity, contradicting the claim.
hidden_timestamp: Does the negative relationship appear only in the aggregated data, while within each department the relationship is positive?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If effects are evaluated within departments (or properly adjusted for department), the data described indicate flexible schedules are associated with higher productivity, not lower.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the claim relies on the aggregate comparison across departments, it can be entirely driven by department composition (Simpson’s paradox) and does not justify a causal decrease claim.

wise_refusal: No. This is Simpson’s paradox: the company-wide aggregate suggests flexibility lowers productivity, but within every department flexible schedules are better. Department confounds both assignment and productivity, so the aggregate comparison is misleading and does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: Because the within-department comparisons reverse the aggregate, the claimed negative causal effect is contradicted once the confounder (department) is accounted for.

scenario: A company wants to boost real productivity (e.g., project completion) and introduces a bonus for sending the highest number of emails per week. Email counts increase sharply, but many emails are trivial or redundant and project completion rates do not improve.
claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, workplace productivity will increase.
label: NO

X.name: bonus incentive tied to email volume

Z: Email volume (proxy metric being optimized)
Email quality/value decoupling once the proxy becomes the target

causal_structure: Incentives increase the proxy (email count) but change behavior in ways that break the proxy–outcome link, so increasing Z does not necessarily increase Y.
key_insight: When a proxy becomes a target, it can be gamed and stop reflecting the intended outcome (Goodhart’s law).
hidden_timestamp: Does the intervention improve the true outcome (project completion) or only inflate the proxy (email volume)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If incentives were aligned to true productivity (completed milestones/quality output) rather than email count, then the intervention could plausibly increase productivity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the incentive targets email volume and the scenario shows project completion does not improve, the causal claim that productivity increases is not supported.

wise_refusal: No. The bonus makes employees maximize email count, which is an easily gamed proxy. The scenario shows email volume rises but true productivity does not, so the mechanism is Goodhart’s law: optimizing the metric does not improve the underlying goal.
gold_rationale: Because the policy targets an easily manipulated proxy, the proxy increases without improving real output; therefore the claim is flawed.

scenario: A company tries to increase real productivity by rewarding employees for sending more emails per day. Employees respond by sending many more emails, including unnecessary ones, while project completion rates do not improve.
claim: If we incentivize employees to send more emails, overall productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Email count (proxy being optimized)
Gaming/low-value email inflation that breaks proxy–outcome relationship

causal_structure: X increases the proxy Z (emails) but behavior shifts to maximize Z without affecting Y, demonstrating Goodhart’s law.
key_insight: Rewarding a proxy can inflate the proxy without improving the intended outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Is the observed improvement in the proxy metric (emails) rather than in the true outcome (projects completed)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the reward were tied to true output (milestones completed/quality measures), then the incentive could plausibly raise productivity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the reward targets email count and true output does not improve (as stated), the claim that productivity increases is not supported.

wise_refusal: No. This is Goodhart’s law: when email count is rewarded, employees inflate emails (often low-value) without improving real productivity. Since project completion does not improve, the causal claim fails in this scenario.
gold_rationale: Because the intervention optimizes an easily gamed proxy, the proxy rises while the true outcome does not, so the claim is flawed.

scenario: A company introduces a wellness program encouraging short stretching breaks. In the first few weeks, productivity rises. Over time, some teams adapt by taking longer and more frequent breaks, and overall productivity returns to baseline. The company is tempted to claim that assigning regular stretching breaks increases productivity in general.
claim: If we assign employees to take regular stretching breaks, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Behavioral adaptation (longer/more frequent breaks over time)
Dynamic feedback where the policy changes behavior that offsets initial benefits

causal_structure: X may increase Y initially, but X also induces adaptation Z that reduces Y over time, canceling the intended effect.
key_insight: An intervention can trigger behavioral responses that negate or reverse its intended effect (backfire mechanism).
hidden_timestamp: Is the claim about a sustained productivity increase, even though the scenario shows the effect disappears after adaptation?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the claim is limited to the short-term window before teams adapt, a short-run productivity increase could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the claim is interpreted as a general/sustained productivity increase, the scenario contradicts it because adaptation removes the gain and productivity returns to baseline.

wise_refusal: No. The scenario shows a backfire mechanism over time: productivity rises initially, but teams adapt by taking longer/more frequent breaks and the benefit disappears. That does not support a general claim that assigning stretching breaks increases productivity.
gold_rationale: Because adaptation negates the initial improvement, the simple causal claim of a sustained increase is not supported in this scenario.

scenario: A manager notices that employees who receive extra training often later have higher performance reviews. Based on this, she wants to assign extra training to everyone to improve performance. However, in this office, extra training is primarily assigned as a remedial action to employees who currently have low performance reviews.
claim: If we assign extra training sessions to employees, their performance reviews will improve.
label: NO

Z: Current/initial performance level (triggers training assignment)
Remedial assignment rule (training given because performance is low)

causal_structure: Low performance (baseline Y or a close proxy) causes training assignment (X). Without exogenous assignment, the observed pattern cannot be interpreted as X causing Y.
key_insight: Training is assigned because performance is low (reverse direction), so the association does not identify the effect of assigning training broadly.
hidden_timestamp: Is extra training assigned reactively based on already-low performance reviews?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees were randomly assigned to extra training regardless of current performance (or under a credible design controlling for baseline performance), the causal effect of training could be evaluated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If training is assigned mainly as remediation for low performers, the observed association does not support the causal claim because the direction runs from performance to training assignment.

wise_refusal: No. Extra training is assigned because employees are already performing poorly, so the relationship is driven by reverse causation (and baseline differences), not necessarily by training causing improvements. A causal claim needs exogenous assignment or a design that properly handles baseline performance.
gold_rationale: Because the intervention is triggered by low performance, the observed pattern cannot be interpreted as the effect of assigning training to employees in general.

scenario: A company wants to estimate whether assigning employees to use a new productivity app increases monthly completed tasks. After assignment, employees naturally vary in how many app features they use. The analyst adjusts for the number of app features used when estimating the effect of app assignment on completed tasks.
claim: If we assign employees to use the new productivity app, their monthly completed tasks will increase.
label: NO

X.name: assignment to use the productivity app

Z: Number of app features used (measured after assignment; downstream mediator)

causal_structure: Assignment (X) affects feature use (Z), which affects tasks (Y). Conditioning on Z blocks part of the causal pathway and biases a total-effect claim.
key_insight: Feature use is downstream of assignment; controlling for it removes part of the app’s effect and can invalidate a total-effect claim.
hidden_timestamp: Is feature use determined after the app is assigned (i.e., affected by X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the goal is the total effect of assignment, the analysis should not adjust for feature use; without post-treatment controls, the total effect could be evaluated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analyst adjusts for post-assignment feature use, the regression does not support a total-effect claim because it conditions on a mediator.

wise_refusal: No. Feature use happens after assignment and is caused by it. Adjusting for this mediator blocks part of the app’s impact on completed tasks, so the analysis result does not justify the claim about the total effect of assignment increasing tasks.
gold_rationale: Because the model controls for a post-treatment mediator, it does not support a causal claim about the total effect of app assignment on task completion.

scenario: A health insurer evaluates whether starting a new diabetes coaching program lowers the chance of diabetes-related hospitalization within 12 months. They define the coaching group as members who enroll at any time during the first 3 months after January 1. Members who never enroll are the comparison group. The analysis starts counting hospitalizations from January 1 for everyone and reports fewer hospitalizations in the coaching group. However, members classified as enrolled must have avoided hospitalization long enough to enroll during that first 3-month window.
claim: If we assign members to start the diabetes coaching program, their 12-month diabetes-related hospitalization risk will decrease.
label: NO

X.name: enrolling in diabetes coaching during months 1–3

Y.name: diabetes-related hospitalization within 12 months from Jan 1

Z: Immortal time: remaining enrolled and hospitalization-free until enrollment occurs
Baseline diabetes severity / comorbidity burden
Healthcare engagement affecting enrollment and hospitalization risk

causal_structure: To be labeled X=1, a member must survive/event-free long enough to enroll. Early hospitalizations force X=0. This built-in selection makes X=1 look safer even without a true effect.
key_insight: Defining treatment by future enrollment while counting outcomes from baseline creates immortal time bias.
hidden_timestamp: Is X defined using future enrollment during months 1–3 while hospitalizations are counted starting at baseline (Jan 1)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If members were assigned at baseline (e.g., randomized or otherwise exogenous) or if follow-up started at each person’s enrollment with time-varying methods, the causal effect of coaching could be estimated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If enrollment during months 1–3 defines X but outcomes are counted from Jan 1 without time-varying handling, the observed lower hospitalization rate can be explained by immortal time bias rather than coaching.

wise_refusal: No. Members classified as enrolled must remain hospitalization-free long enough to enroll, while early hospitalizations automatically place members into the never-enrolled group. That immortal time makes the coaching group look artificially better even if coaching has no effect. A causal estimate requires baseline assignment or time-varying methods that avoid counting pre-enrollment time as treated.
gold_rationale: Because exposure is defined using future enrollment while follow-up starts at baseline, immortal time bias can fully explain the apparent benefit, so the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: A company studies whether completing an optional 6-week leadership certificate reduces the chance of quitting within the next year. They classify employees as certificate completers if they finish the program at any point in the first 6 months after hiring. They then compare 1-year quit rates measured from the hire date between completers and non-completers, finding completers quit less. But employees who quit early cannot complete the certificate and are automatically counted as non-completers.
claim: If we assign new hires to complete the leadership certificate, they will be less likely to quit within one year.
label: NO

X.name: completing the leadership certificate within 6 months of hire

Z: Immortal time: remaining employed long enough to complete the certificate
Baseline motivation / commitment
Manager support / team culture affecting completion and quitting

causal_structure: Completer status uses future information (finish within 6 months) while quitting is measured from hire. Early quitters must be non-completers, creating immortal time bias.
key_insight: Completers are guaranteed to have survived (not quit) until completion, which mechanically lowers their observed quit rate.
hidden_timestamp: Is X defined by completing the certificate within months 0–6 while quitting is counted from month 0?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees were assigned at hire to mandatory certificate vs no certificate (or if treated person-time started only after completion using time-varying methods), the causal effect on quitting could be estimated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If completers are defined by future completion while quit outcomes are counted from hire without correction, the lower quit rate among completers can arise from immortal time bias even if the certificate has no effect.

wise_refusal: No. Completers must remain employed long enough to finish, so the pre-completion period is ‘immortal’ time where quitting cannot occur for those labeled X=1. Early quitters can never be completers and inflate quitting in X=0. You need baseline assignment or time-varying methods to avoid immortal time bias.
gold_rationale: Because completion is defined using future information while follow-up starts at hire, immortal time bias invalidates the causal claim.

scenario: A city evaluates whether receiving a home fire-safety inspection reduces the chance of a household fire within 2 years. Households are labeled inspected if they schedule and complete an inspection anytime in the first year after moving in. The city compares fires over 2 years starting from move-in date and finds fewer fires among the inspected group. But to be classified as inspected, a household must remain at the address and avoid a major fire long enough to complete the inspection.
claim: If we assign households to get a home fire-safety inspection, their probability of having a household fire within 2 years will decrease.
label: NO

X.name: completing a fire-safety inspection within 1 year of move-in

Y.name: household fire within 2 years from move-in

Z: Immortal time: remaining event-free and resident until inspection completion
Baseline home safety quality (wiring, alarms)
Homeowner conscientiousness affecting inspection and fire risk

causal_structure: Inspection status is defined by future completion, but fires are counted from move-in. Early fires cannot occur in X=1 during pre-inspection time by definition, producing immortal time bias.
key_insight: The ‘inspected’ group is partly defined by having avoided a fire long enough to get inspected, biasing the comparison.
hidden_timestamp: Is inspection status assigned using future completion within the first year while fires are counted from move-in?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If inspections were assigned at move-in or if analysis treated inspection as time-varying starting at the inspection date (not counting pre-inspection time as exposed), the causal effect could be estimated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If inspection is defined by future completion but fires are counted from baseline without time-varying correction, the apparent benefit can be explained by immortal time bias rather than inspection effectiveness.

wise_refusal: No. The inspected group must remain at the residence and fire-free long enough to complete inspection, creating immortal time bias. Early fires automatically place households in the non-inspected group. A causal estimate needs baseline assignment or time-varying methods that start exposure at the inspection date.
gold_rationale: Because exposure is defined by future inspection completion while follow-up starts at move-in, immortal time bias can explain the result, so the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: A clinic assesses whether patients who stay on a new blood-pressure medication for at least 90 days have fewer strokes over the next year than patients who do not. Patients are categorized as adherent (X=1) if pharmacy records show continuous refills for 90 days after the first prescription; otherwise X=0. Strokes are counted starting from the first prescription date. Patients who have an early stroke or severe side effects may stop refilling and are automatically in X=0, while X=1 requires surviving and remaining stable long enough to reach day 90.
claim: If we assign patients to stay on the medication for at least 90 days, their 1-year stroke risk will decrease.
label: NO

X.name: continuous adherence for the first 90 days

Y.name: stroke within 1 year from first prescription

Z: Immortal time: being stroke-free and stable enough to reach 90-day adherence
Baseline stroke risk / cardiovascular severity
Medication tolerance/side effects affecting adherence and outcomes

causal_structure: X is defined using future adherence through day 90, while Y is counted from day 0. Early strokes prevent reaching X=1, mechanically inflating Y in X=0 and biasing the estimate.
key_insight: The ‘adherent for 90 days’ group is selected by surviving event-free to day 90, creating a built-in protective bias.
hidden_timestamp: Is adherence defined over the first 90 days while strokes are counted from the first prescription date (day 0)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If patients were randomized at day 0 to medication vs placebo (intention-to-treat) or adherence were analyzed as a time-varying exposure without crediting pre-day-90 time as treated, the causal effect could be estimated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If ‘90-day adherence’ defines X while counting strokes from day 0 without correcting immortal time, the lower stroke rate in X=1 can reflect selection of healthier/stabler patients rather than medication benefit.

wise_refusal: No. Classifying patients by future 90-day adherence creates immortal time bias: patients must remain stroke-free long enough to qualify as adherent, while early strokes move patients into the non-adherent group. This can make adherence look protective even if the medication has no effect.
gold_rationale: Because exposure is defined using future adherence while follow-up starts at baseline, immortal time bias invalidates the causal claim.

scenario: A gym wants to know whether joining a personal-training plan reduces injuries over the next 6 months. Members are labeled as training (X=1) if they sign up any time within the first 8 weeks after starting membership; everyone else is X=0. Injuries are measured starting from membership start date. Members who get injured early often pause workouts or quit before they can sign up, so they must be counted as X=0.
claim: If we assign new members to join personal training, their risk of injury over the next 6 months will decrease.
label: NO

X.name: signing up for personal training within the first 8 weeks

Y.name: injury within 6 months from membership start

Z: Immortal time: remaining injury-free and active long enough to sign up
Baseline fitness / prior injury history
Exercise intensity / risk-taking behavior

causal_structure: X is defined using future sign-up within 8 weeks, while injuries are counted from day 0. Early injuries prevent sign-up and force X=0, producing immortal time bias.
key_insight: Only members who remain injury-free long enough can enter the training group, making training look protective even if it is not.
hidden_timestamp: Is training status determined by future sign-up within 8 weeks while injuries are counted starting at membership start?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If members were assigned at day 0 to personal training vs standard membership (or training were treated as time-varying starting at sign-up), the causal effect on injuries could be estimated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X is defined by later sign-up but injuries are counted from day 0 without addressing immortal time, the lower injury rate in X=1 can be explained by selection (only injury-free members can qualify).

wise_refusal: No. The training group is defined by a future event (signing up within 8 weeks), so members must stay injury-free and engaged long enough to be classified as X=1. Early injuries automatically land in X=0, inflating injury rates there. That immortal time bias can create a spurious protective effect.
gold_rationale: Because exposure is defined by future sign-up while follow-up begins at baseline, immortal time bias can explain the association, so the claim is not supported.

scenario: A customer-support team introduces a new script only for agents whose CSAT scores were among the lowest 10% last month.
