This month, those agents’ CSAT scores improve, and the manager concludes the script caused the improvement. But the targeted agents were selected based on unusually low scores that likely included random fluctuations.
claim: Giving the new support script to low-performing agents causes their CSAT scores to increase next month.
label: NO

X.name: receiving the new support script due to being in the lowest 10% last month

Z: Selection on an extreme low baseline metric (lowest 10%)
Random month-to-month CSAT noise (ticket mix, customer mood)
Regression to the mean after an extreme low month

causal_structure: Selecting agents with extreme low baseline scores guarantees some rebound toward typical performance even without intervention (regression to the mean).
key_insight: Improvement after targeting extreme low performers can occur mechanically due to regression to the mean, not because the script works.
hidden_timestamp: Were agents selected for treatment because of an extreme low CSAT month (lowest 10%)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If similarly low-CSAT agents were randomly split into script vs no-script (or compared to a matched control group), improvements beyond regression to the mean could be attributed to the script.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only the extreme low-CSAT agents receive the script and then improve, the improvement can be explained by regression to the mean and noise rather than a causal effect of the script.

wise_refusal: No. The script was given only to agents selected for an unusually low CSAT month, and their scores would typically rebound toward their usual level even without changes. Without a comparable control group or randomization, you can’t separate the script’s effect from regression to the mean.
gold_rationale: Because treatment was targeted based on an extreme baseline measurement, regression to the mean can explain the improvement, so the causal claim is not justified.

scenario: A landlord offers a rent-discount retention deal only to tenants who complained the most last month. The next month, those tenants submit fewer complaints. The landlord claims the discount reduced complaints, but tenants were selected when complaint levels were unusually high due to temporary events.
claim: Offering the rent discount to high-complaint tenants causes their complaint frequency to decrease the next month.
label: NO

X.name: receiving a rent discount after an extreme high complaint month

Z: Temporary disruptions last month (construction, elevator outage)
Selection on an extreme high baseline complaint level
Regression to the mean after a temporary spike

causal_structure: Tenants are selected at an extreme high complaint period; complaints often fall afterward due to both regression to the mean and the end of temporary disruptions.
key_insight: A decrease after an extreme spike does not prove the discount caused the change.
hidden_timestamp: Were tenants selected for the discount because of an extreme spike in complaints last month?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If similarly high-complaint tenants were randomly offered the discount vs not (or compared to a matched control group), any additional reduction beyond regression to the mean could be attributed to the discount.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the discount is offered only after an extreme complaint month, the reduction can be explained by regression to the mean and temporary issues resolving rather than the discount.

wise_refusal: No. The tenants were chosen after an unusually high complaint month likely driven by temporary problems, so complaints would tend to drop afterward anyway. Without a comparable control group or random assignment, you can’t infer the discount caused the reduction rather than regression to the mean.
gold_rationale: Because treatment was targeted based on an extreme baseline outcome, regression to the mean can explain the observed decrease, so the causal claim is not supported.

scenario: A city compares districts and finds that districts with higher average daily cycling rates also have lower average obesity rates. The city council claims: 'If we assign an individual resident to cycle daily, that resident’s obesity risk will decrease.' But the analysis is based on district-level averages; districts with more cycling may also have healthier food environments, higher walkability, and different demographics.
claim: If we assign an individual resident to cycle daily, their obesity risk will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Ecological aggregation (district averages, not individual-level data)
District walkability / built environment
District food environment / socioeconomic status / demographics

causal_structure: The observed association is between group averages, which can be driven by group-level confounders and does not identify individual-level effects.
key_insight: A district-level correlation does not imply that making a specific person cycle will reduce their obesity risk (ecological fallacy).
hidden_timestamp: Is the evidence aggregated at the district level rather than measured for individuals receiving a cycling intervention?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we had individual-level causal evidence (e.g., randomized cycling intervention or longitudinal individual data with appropriate controls), we could evaluate whether cycling reduces obesity risk for individuals.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we only observe district-level averages, the association can reflect district characteristics rather than the effect of cycling on individuals, so the individual-level causal claim is not justified.

wise_refusal: No. This inference jumps from district averages to individual causation. Districts that cycle more often differ in walkability, diet environments, income, and demographics, which can affect obesity. Without individual-level causal evidence, you cannot claim assigning a specific person to cycle daily will reduce their obesity risk.
gold_rationale: Because the relationship is measured at the group level and may be driven by group-level confounders, it does not support an individual-level causal claim (ecological fallacy).

scenario: A company’s HR team compares office locations worldwide and finds that offices with higher average employee engagement survey scores also have higher average quarterly productivity. Leadership announces: 'If we force an individual employee to be more engaged, their productivity will increase.' But the data are aggregated by office, and offices differ in leadership quality, market conditions, staffing levels, and project mix.
claim: If we assign an individual employee to increase their engagement, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Ecological aggregation (office averages, not individual-level causal evidence)
Office leadership quality / management practices
Office market conditions / staffing / project mix

causal_structure: The correlation is between office-level averages and can be driven by office-level confounders; it does not identify the causal effect of changing engagement for an individual employee.
key_insight: Group-level correlations cannot be used to make individual-level causal claims (ecological fallacy).
hidden_timestamp: Is the evidence an office-level correlation rather than an individual-level engagement intervention with individual outcomes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we had individual-level causal variation (e.g., randomized engagement intervention) and measured individual productivity, we could estimate whether increasing engagement causes productivity changes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we only observe office-level averages, office differences (leadership, resources, market) can explain the correlation, so the individual-level causal claim is not justified.

wise_refusal: No. Offices differ in many factors that affect both engagement and productivity. A positive correlation between office averages does not prove that forcing a particular employee’s engagement higher would raise their productivity. You would need an individual-level causal design to support that claim.
gold_rationale: Because the association is measured at the group level and subject to group-level confounding, it does not support an individual-level causal statement (ecological fallacy).

scenario: A company rolls out a wellness program that offers a free smart scale and step tracker to employees who enroll (X). Three months later, HR reports that participants have a larger drop in average body weight (Y) than non-participants. However, participants' weights are captured frequently and precisely by smart scales, while non-participants' weights are mostly self-reported on a quarterly survey. The apparent difference may reflect different measurement methods rather than true weight change.
claim: The wellness program caused employees to lose more weight over three months.
label: NO

X.name: Enrollment in the wellness program (receiving smart-scale monitoring)

Z: Different weight measurement methods across groups (smart scale vs self-report)
Differential misreporting/social desirability in self-reported weight
Baseline health motivation differences between enrollees and non-enrollees

causal_structure: Exposure status determines the measurement instrument for Y (objective frequent scale readings vs sparse self-report), creating differential measurement error that can mimic a true X→Y effect.
key_insight: When Y is measured differently across exposure groups, apparent treatment effects can be measurement artifacts.
hidden_timestamp: Were participants and non-participants weighed using the same instrument and schedule (same scale, same frequency, same reporting rules)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If weight is measured identically for both groups (same calibrated scale and schedule) and participants still lose more, then the program could have a causal effect on weight loss.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If participants have objective frequent smart-scale readings while non-participants rely on sparse self-reports, the observed difference can be due to measurement bias rather than true weight loss caused by the program.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute the weight-loss difference to the program because weight is measured differently across groups, which can create a spurious gap.
gold_rationale: Differential outcome measurement by exposure status can generate apparent effects even when true weight changes are similar.

scenario: A school introduces noise-reducing classroom panels in some rooms (X) and evaluates whether students are more on-task (Y). In panel-equipped rooms, teachers use an on-task rubric with an app that prompts ratings every 10 minutes. In non-panel rooms, teachers fill out a single end-of-day on-task estimate from memory. The school reports higher on-task rates in panel rooms, but the outcome is measured with different instruments and timing across groups.
claim: Installing noise-reducing panels caused students to be more on-task during class.
label: NO

Y.name: Student on-task behavior rate during class

Z: Different on-task measurement protocol by group (frequent prompted rubric vs end-of-day recall)
Prompting/monitoring intensity changes due to the app
Baseline classroom behavior norms differ across rooms

causal_structure: X determines the measurement process for Y (frequent prompted ratings vs retrospective estimate), producing differential measurement that can create spurious differences in observed Y.
key_insight: If the instrument and sampling frequency for Y differ by X, the comparison does not isolate the causal effect of X.
hidden_timestamp: Was on-task behavior measured using the same rubric, sampling schedule, and observers in both panel and non-panel rooms?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both groups use the same on-task measurement protocol and panel rooms still show higher on-task behavior, then panels may have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If panel rooms use frequent prompted ratings while non-panel rooms rely on end-of-day recall, the difference could be a measurement artifact rather than a true panel effect.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude the panels improved on-task behavior because the outcome is measured differently across classrooms, which can change the observed averages.
gold_rationale: Differential measurement and sampling can induce apparent treatment effects without any real behavioral change.

scenario: A clinic introduces a new phone-based follow-up program (X) to improve medication adherence (Y). Patients in the program report higher adherence than patients not in the program. However, program patients report adherence via weekly phone calls with a nurse, while non-program patients report adherence via an anonymous monthly online form. The different reporting channels and frequency may change how accurately adherence is measured and may also change willingness to admit missed doses.
claim: The phone-based follow-up program caused patients to have higher medication adherence.
label: NO

X.name: Enrollment in weekly nurse phone follow-up program

Z: Different adherence measurement/reporting modes (weekly nurse calls vs anonymous monthly form)
Social desirability/underreporting of missed doses when speaking to a nurse
Baseline patient engagement differences between groups

causal_structure: X changes the context and frequency of Y measurement (nurse calls vs anonymous form), creating differential misclassification of adherence by exposure status.
key_insight: Changing how Y is measured can change reported Y even if true adherence is unchanged.
hidden_timestamp: Was adherence measured identically in both groups (same reporting channel, frequency, and anonymity), or with an objective measure (e.g., refill data)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If adherence is measured objectively and identically in both groups (e.g., refill records/electronic monitors) and the program group is still higher, that supports a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If adherence is self-reported via different modes and frequencies, differences may reflect reporting bias rather than a true causal effect of the program.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute higher adherence to the program because adherence is measured and reported differently across groups, which can bias the comparison.
gold_rationale: Differential outcome measurement by exposure status can create spurious differences in reported adherence.

scenario: A doctor advises some patients to try an elimination diet (X) to reduce migraines (Y). After two months, patients who tried the diet report fewer migraines than patients who did not. However, migraine counts are collected by asking patients to recall how many migraine days they had in the past two months. Patients who invested effort into the diet may be more motivated to remember improvements and undercount episodes, while others may recall differently.
claim: Trying the elimination diet caused patients to have fewer migraine days over two months.
label: NO

X.name: Trying an elimination diet for two months

Y.name: Number of migraine days over two months (recalled at end)

Z: Differential recall/motivated reporting of migraine days by diet participation
Baseline migraine severity
Use of rescue medication during the period

causal_structure: Y is measured via retrospective recall, and exposure status can influence memory/interpretation of episodes, producing differential measurement error in Y.
key_insight: When Y is recalled after the fact, expectations and effort can bias recall differently across exposure groups.
hidden_timestamp: Were migraine days recorded prospectively during the two months (same diary protocol for both groups), or only reconstructed from memory at the end?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If migraine days are logged prospectively with the same protocol for both groups (ideally under random assignment) and the diet group still has fewer days, then a causal effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If migraine counts come from two-month retrospective recall and diet participants are more motivated to report improvement, the difference can be recall bias rather than a true diet effect.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude the diet reduced migraines because the outcome is based on retrospective recall that can be biased differently for people who tried the diet.
gold_rationale: Differential recall of outcomes by exposure status can create spurious treatment effects.

scenario: A university offers a time-management workshop (X) and later evaluates whether it reduces all-nighters (Y) during finals. Two weeks after finals, students are asked to recall how many nights they stayed up past 3 a.m. during finals week. Students who attended the workshop may feel they should have improved and may underreport all-nighters, while non-attendees may recall differently or overreport due to stress salience.
claim: Attending the time-management workshop caused students to pull fewer all-nighters during finals.
label: NO

Y.name: Number of all-nighters during finals week (recalled two weeks later)

Z: Differential recall/underreporting among attendees due to demand effects
Baseline course load difficulty
Student conscientiousness/motivation

causal_structure: Y is measured retrospectively after finals, and workshop participation can influence recall and reporting, producing differential error in Y by X.
key_insight: When outcomes are recalled later, motivational/demand effects can bias reports and mimic causal effects.
hidden_timestamp: Were all-nighters measured in real time during finals (sleep diary/wearable) with the same protocol for both groups, or only recalled two weeks later?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If all-nighters are tracked prospectively with the same protocol for attendees and non-attendees (ideally randomized) and attendees have fewer all-nighters, the workshop could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all-nighters are measured only by post-hoc recall and attendees feel pressure to report improvement, the observed difference may be recall bias.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute fewer all-nighters to the workshop because the outcome is based on delayed recall that may be biased differently for attendees and non-attendees.
gold_rationale: Differential recall of outcomes across exposure groups can generate spurious workshop effects.

scenario: A company introduces a no-meeting Wednesday policy (X) and later observes employees send fewer late-night emails (Y). The evaluation compares late-night email counts in the month after the policy to the month before. But during the same period, a major product launch ended and workload dropped sharply, and the policy was announced midway through the month. Most of the reduction in late-night emails began immediately after the launch ended, before the policy took effect.
claim: Implementing no-meeting Wednesdays caused employees to send fewer late-night emails.
label: NO

Z: Outcome trend changes before policy implementation (launch ended first)
Policy begins mid-window while Y is aggregated over month
Workload drop after launch ending affects late-night emailing

causal_structure: A time-varying factor (launch ending) changes Y before X is implemented; aggregating over wide windows obscures ordering and can misattribute the change to X.
key_insight: If Y changes before X actually starts, X cannot be the cause of that change.
hidden_timestamp: On what exact date did the policy take effect, and did late-night emails start declining before that date?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If daily timestamps show late-night emails drop after the policy takes effect (not before) and workload is accounted for, then the policy could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If late-night emails decline immediately after the launch ends and before the policy starts, the reduction cannot be attributed to the policy.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute the email reduction to no-meeting Wednesdays because the decline begins before the policy takes effect and coincides with a workload drop.
gold_rationale: Temporal ordering is inconsistent with X causing Y when Y shifts prior to X implementation.

scenario: A gym starts offering a new high-intensity class (X) and advertises that members who take the class lose more weight (Y) over the next month. The gym compares weight change among those who enrolled in the class to those who did not. However, enrollment opens only after a free body composition scan week, and many members decide to join the class after seeing they gained weight on the scan. Weight change is computed from the scan date to one month later, so the exposure decision is partly driven by earlier outcome-related information.
claim: Taking the new high-intensity class caused members to lose more weight over the next month.
label: NO

X.name: Enrolling in / taking the new high-intensity class

Y.name: Weight change over the next month

Z: Prior weight scan feedback (weight gain) influences enrollment decision
Outcome window starts at a timepoint that triggered exposure (scan date)
Concurrent behavior changes after scan (diet/exercise) correlated with enrollment

causal_structure: Outcome-related information (scan) precedes and influences X, and Y is computed from that pre-exposure anchor, mixing pre/post dynamics and confusing causal direction.
key_insight: If exposure is triggered by prior outcome signals, naive comparisons can misattribute subsequent changes to the exposure.
hidden_timestamp: Was weight change measured strictly after class participation began, rather than from the scan date that influenced enrollment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If enrollment is assigned independently of scan feedback and weight change is measured only after class start, then the class could be evaluated causally.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If people enroll because of scan results and weight change is computed from the scan date, the observed loss may reflect response to feedback and other changes, not the class effect.

wise_refusal: We cannot claim the class caused weight loss because enrollment is influenced by prior weight feedback and the outcome window is anchored before exposure begins.
gold_rationale: Ambiguous timing and outcome-driven exposure selection undermine identification of X→Y.

scenario: A school district adopts a mindfulness app for students (X) and claims it improves math test scores (Y). The district report says mindfulness improves the brain but does not articulate how app usage would translate into improved math performance (e.g., via attention, reduced test anxiety, or increased study time), nor does it measure any intermediate process. Participation is optional, and teachers who promote the app also introduce extra test-prep sessions.
claim: Introducing the mindfulness app caused math test scores to increase.
label: NO

X.name: Student use of the mindfulness app

Z: Unspecified/unmeasured pathway from app use to math performance
Extra test-prep sessions coincide with app promotion
Student motivation/engagement affects both app use and scores

causal_structure: The claim asserts X→Y without specifying or measuring intermediate mechanisms; a more direct alternative pathway (teacher test-prep) can explain Y changes.
key_insight: Without a specified/measured mechanism (and with plausible alternative pathways), attributing Y changes to X is an unsupported causal leap.
hidden_timestamp: Did app use change a measurable intermediate (attention, anxiety, study time) before scores changed, and were these intermediates measured for both users and non-users?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the district specifies and measures a plausible intermediate (e.g., attention/anxiety/study time) that changes due to X and scores rise under a strong design (ideally randomized), then the claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the justification is vague and intermediates are unmeasured while extra test-prep coincides with app promotion, then you cannot attribute score gains to the app.

wise_refusal: We cannot credit higher math scores to the mindfulness app because the mechanism is unspecified and unmeasured, and concurrent test-prep provides a direct alternative explanation.
gold_rationale: Mechanism gaps plus plausible alternative pathways make the causal attribution unsupported.

scenario: A city adds more bike lanes (X) and claims this reduces traffic congestion (Y) because average car travel times decreased the following year. The city’s report does not explain the mechanism by which adding bike lanes would reduce congestion in this context and does not measure whether car trips decreased or whether bike commuting increased. During the same year, a major employer adopted remote work policies and a highway construction project ended.
claim: Adding bike lanes caused traffic congestion to decrease.
label: NO

Y.name: Traffic congestion / average car travel time

Z: No measured mechanism (mode shift/car VMT change not assessed)
Remote work adoption reduces commuting demand
Highway construction ending increases road capacity

causal_structure: The claim relies on an unmeasured causal pathway from bike lanes to congestion while major concurrent demand/supply changes can explain Y.
key_insight: Without measuring the pathway (e.g., mode shift) and ruling out concurrent changes, the attribution to X is unsupported.
hidden_timestamp: Did mode share (bike trips) and car travel demand (car VMT) change after bike lanes were added, and were those intermediates measured?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the city measures and shows a plausible mechanism (e.g., reduced car VMT via mode shift attributable to the lanes) and uses a design controlling for remote work and construction, then the claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the report does not specify/measure how bike lanes reduce congestion and major concurrent factors plausibly explain the change, the causal attribution to bike lanes is not supported.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude bike lanes reduced congestion because the report does not measure the mechanism and concurrent changes provide alternative explanations.
gold_rationale: Mechanism is unmeasured and competing explanations are strong, so X→Y is not established.

scenario: A company introduces an always-on productivity dashboard that publicly ranks employees by tasks completed (X) to motivate higher productivity (Y). After rollout, average task completion drops and error rates increase. The intended mechanism is that visibility and competition increase effort, but the policy may backfire: employees feel monitored and stressed, shift to easy tasks to game the ranking, avoid helping teammates, and rush work, reducing true productivity and quality.
claim: Introducing a public productivity ranking dashboard caused overall productivity to increase.
label: NO

Z: Backfire pathway: stress/pressure and gaming incentives induced by public ranking
Shift toward easy tasks/metric gaming reduces quality-adjusted output
Reduced collaboration/helping behavior lowers true productivity

causal_structure: X changes incentives and can activate opposing mechanisms (stress, gaming, reduced cooperation) that decrease true Y even if the intended motivation mechanism exists.
key_insight: An intervention designed to improve outcomes can plausibly worsen them through unintended incentive and stress pathways.
hidden_timestamp: Did quality-adjusted output improve after the dashboard while stress, gaming, and errors did not increase (i.e., did the intended pathway dominate the backfire pathways)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the dashboard includes anti-gaming/quality safeguards and evidence shows quality-adjusted output rises without higher error rates or reduced collaboration, then the claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If public ranking increases stress and gaming (more low-value tasks, more errors, less collaboration), then the mechanism backfires and overall productivity will not increase.

wise_refusal: We cannot claim the dashboard increased productivity because it can plausibly backfire via stress and gaming, which may reduce quality-adjusted output.
gold_rationale: Backfire mechanisms create a credible path from X to worse Y, contradicting the simple intended causal story.

scenario: A city rolls out aggressive anti-littering fines with frequent enforcement (X) to reduce litter in parks (Y). After the policy, park staff record more hidden trash (stuffed into bushes) and fewer people using trash cans. The intended mechanism is deterrence, but it may backfire: visitors fear being seen holding trash near bins where enforcement is concentrated, avoid bins, and hide trash to avoid penalties.
claim: Increasing anti-littering fines and enforcement caused litter in parks to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Aggressive anti-littering fines plus increased enforcement

Y.name: Amount of litter in parks (true total litter)

Z: Backfire pathway: avoidance/hiding behavior in response to enforcement hotspots
Behavioral displacement (avoiding bins, hiding trash) changes where litter appears
Park crowding/event days affect trash volume independently

causal_structure: X alters incentives and can induce avoidance/displacement behaviors that increase hidden litter or distort observed litter patterns, opposing the intended deterrence pathway.
key_insight: Deterrence policies can induce unintended behavioral adaptation that worsens the outcome or shifts it out of sight.
hidden_timestamp: Was litter measured comprehensively (including hidden/displaced trash) before and after the policy, rather than only visible litter near bins?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If comprehensive audits (including hidden trash) show total litter decreases after enforcement and there is no evidence of displacement/hiding, then the claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If people respond by hiding trash or shifting where they litter to avoid enforcement, the mechanism backfires and total litter may not decrease (and can increase).

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude enforcement reduced litter because it can plausibly backfire by shifting trash into hidden locations and changing disposal behavior.
gold_rationale: A plausible opposing mechanism (avoidance/displacement) undermines the simple deterrence interpretation.

scenario: A gym advertises a new 8-week training program (X) and highlights that most people who complete the program lose significant weight (Y). Their published results only include members who finished all 8 weeks and attended at least 80% of sessions. Many participants who struggled stopped attending early and are excluded from the analysis. The gym then claims enrolling in the program causes weight loss, but the comparison is restricted to completers.
claim: Enrolling in the 8-week gym program caused participants to lose significant weight.
label: NO

Z: Selection on completion/high attendance (only completers included in analysis)
Motivation/self-discipline affects both completion and weight loss
Injury/health constraints affect attendance and weight change

causal_structure: Analysis conditions on a post-exposure selection variable (completion) influenced by baseline factors and early progress, biasing estimates of X→Y.
key_insight: Restricting analysis to survivors/completers can make an intervention look effective even if many dropouts do poorly.
hidden_timestamp: Were outcomes analyzed for all enrollees (including dropouts), or only for those who completed the program?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we analyze all enrollees (intention-to-treat) and track outcomes regardless of completion (or randomize assignment), then we could estimate the causal effect of enrolling.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we only include completers/high-attendance participants, the estimate is biased by survivorship and cannot justify the causal claim for all enrollees.

wise_refusal: We cannot claim enrollment caused weight loss because the analysis only includes completers, creating survivorship bias.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on completion (a post-exposure selection filter) biases the observed association between X and Y.

scenario: A manager observes that employees who choose to work from a quiet room (X) tend to produce higher-quality reports (Y). The manager concludes that assigning employees to the quiet room would improve report quality. However, employees who select the quiet room are often those working on more complex writing tasks and who are more conscientious. Conscientiousness and task type influence both the likelihood of using the quiet room and the quality of reports.
claim: Assigning employees to work from a quiet room caused report quality to increase.
label: NO

Z: Employee conscientiousness/work ethic affects both room choice and report quality
Task type/complexity affects both room choice and report quality
Prior writing skill affects report quality and may influence room choice

causal_structure: Pre-exposure variables (conscientiousness, task complexity, skill) influence both X and Y, so comparing X vs not-X is confounded.
key_insight: Selection into the quiet room reflects pre-existing differences that also drive report quality.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees randomly assigned to the quiet room, or were key pre-exposure confounders (task complexity, conscientiousness, writing skill) measured and adjusted for?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees are randomly assigned to the quiet room (or confounders are richly measured and adjusted) and report quality still increases, then the claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If conscientiousness/task type drives both quiet-room use and higher quality, then the naive association is confounded and does not support the causal claim.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude the quiet room causes better reports because employees who choose it differ in conscientiousness and task complexity, which also affect report quality.
gold_rationale: A common-cause confounder explains the association between X and Y.

scenario: A school notices that students who attend after-school tutoring (X) have lower grades (Y) than students who don’t. Administrators conclude that tutoring causes grades to drop and consider canceling the program. But students are typically referred to tutoring after their grades have already fallen. Poor performance leads to tutoring enrollment, not vice versa.
claim: Assigning students to after-school tutoring caused their grades to decrease.
label: NO

Z: Prior low grades trigger tutoring referral/enrollment (early Y drives X)
Teacher referral policy influences tutoring assignment
Home support/motivation affects both tutoring participation and grades

causal_structure: Prior outcome (low grades) causes exposure (tutoring), so the observed association can reflect Y→X rather than X→Y.
key_insight: When treatment is assigned because outcomes are already poor, naive comparisons can falsely suggest treatment harms outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Did tutoring enrollment occur after grades had already declined (baseline/pre-period Y), and were baseline grades accounted for or randomized?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If students are randomly assigned to tutoring regardless of baseline grades (or baseline performance is properly controlled in a strong design) and grades worsen afterward, then the claim could be supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If tutoring is mainly assigned after grades drop, the negative association reflects reverse causation and does not show tutoring causes lower grades.

wise_refusal: We cannot claim tutoring lowers grades because students are typically enrolled after their grades fall, so prior poor performance drives tutoring participation.
gold_rationale: Reverse causation (Y_prior→X) can flip the apparent direction of effect in observational comparisons.

scenario: A sales team is flagged because their weekly conversion rate drops unusually low one week. Management enrolls that team in an intensive sales coaching session (X) the following week. The next month, their conversion rate (Y) rises back toward the company average, and leadership credits the coaching for the improvement. However, the team was selected precisely because they had an unusually bad week, and conversion rates naturally fluctuate week to week.
claim: The intensive sales coaching caused the team's conversion rate to improve.
label: NO

Y.name: Conversion rate over the following month

Z: Selection based on an unusually low baseline week (extreme low performance)
Natural week-to-week variance in conversion rates
Seasonality and lead quality changes across weeks

causal_structure: Teams are chosen for coaching because they had an extreme low outcome; subsequent outcomes tend to move back toward typical levels even without coaching.
key_insight: When you intervene after an extreme measurement, improvement can occur from regression to the mean rather than a true treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Were coached teams selected specifically because they had an unusually low conversion week compared to their usual performance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If teams were randomly assigned to coaching regardless of prior conversion rates (or compared to a matched control selected the same way), then higher conversion could be attributed to coaching.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If coaching was given only because the team had an unusually bad week, the rebound can be explained by regression to the mean rather than coaching.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the coaching caused the improvement because the team was chosen after an unusually bad week, and conversion rates often rebound naturally.
gold_rationale: Selecting units based on extreme outcomes makes post-selection improvements expected even without a causal effect.

scenario: A person checks their credit score and sees it is unusually low compared to recent months. They immediately subscribe to a premium credit-monitoring service (X). Two months later, their credit score (Y) is higher, and they claim the subscription improved their score. But credit scores often bounce after short-term fluctuations (e.g., a temporary high utilization month).
claim: Subscribing to premium credit monitoring caused the credit score to increase.
label: NO

Z: Enrollment triggered by an unusually low score observation
Natural fluctuation due to utilization changes and reporting timing
Concurrent debt repayment or bill timing unrelated to the subscription

causal_structure: Subscription happens in response to an extreme low score; the score later moves toward its typical level due to routine reporting cycles.
key_insight: An apparent improvement after reacting to a low reading can be a statistical rebound.
hidden_timestamp: Did the person subscribe immediately after noticing an unusually low score relative to their recent baseline?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If subscription assignment were independent of the initial score (or compared against a similar group who also had a low score but did not subscribe), then a differential increase could support causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the subscription was prompted by an unusually low score, the increase can reflect regression to the mean and reporting-cycle effects, not a causal impact of monitoring.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute the score increase to the subscription because the subscription was started after an unusually low score that could naturally rebound.
gold_rationale: Intervening after an extreme measurement commonly produces apparent improvements without causal influence.

scenario: Students who score unusually poorly on a midterm are required to attend an extra tutoring session (X). On the final exam, their scores (Y) improve compared to their midterm. The instructor concludes the tutoring caused the improvement. But students were selected because they had an unusually low midterm score, and exam performance varies across tests.
claim: Requiring extra tutoring caused low-scoring students to improve on the final exam.
label: NO

X.name: Mandatory extra tutoring for low midterm scorers

Z: Selection based on an extreme low midterm score
Differences in exam difficulty and content between midterm and final
Increased studying motivated by a bad midterm (regardless of tutoring)

causal_structure: Tutoring is assigned based on an extreme low outcome (midterm), so subsequent scores tend to rise toward typical ability even without tutoring.
key_insight: Improvement after being selected for poor performance is expected even without an effective intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Were students assigned to tutoring solely because they had unusually low midterm scores (rather than random assignment)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If similarly low-scoring students were randomly assigned to tutoring vs no tutoring and the tutored group improved more, that would support a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If tutoring was triggered by an unusually low midterm, observed improvement can be regression to the mean plus changes in motivation or test difficulty.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude tutoring caused the improvement because the group was chosen for unusually poor midterm performance that often rebounds.
gold_rationale: Post-selection changes can reflect statistical rebound rather than intervention effectiveness.

scenario: A runner has an unusually slow 5K time during a hot race. They switch to a new training plan (X) immediately after. At the next 5K a month later, their time (Y) is faster, and they credit the plan. But their prior race was unusually slow due to heat and they typically run faster.
claim: Switching to the new training plan caused the runner’s 5K time to improve.
label: NO

X.name: Switching to a new training plan after a slow race

Y.name: 5K finish time at the next race

Z: Selection based on an unusually slow baseline race
Race-day conditions (temperature, course difficulty, wind)
Random performance variability and recovery status

causal_structure: The plan change is a response to an extreme slow performance; later performance returns toward the runner’s typical level when conditions normalize.
key_insight: A rebound after a bad performance can be mistaken for a training effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was the training plan adopted specifically after an unusually slow race that was atypical for the runner?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the runner compared outcomes across many races under similar conditions, or randomized training blocks, a consistent improvement could support causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the plan followed an unusually slow race driven by conditions, the faster next time can be explained by regression to the mean and better conditions.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute the improvement to the plan because the plan started after an unusually slow race and performance often rebounds naturally.
gold_rationale: Regression to the mean plus changing conditions can create spurious before/after effects.

scenario: A city reports that neighborhoods with higher average mask usage (X) have lower average respiratory illness rates (Y) than other neighborhoods. Officials conclude that increasing mask usage in a neighborhood will reduce illness. However, the data are aggregated at the neighborhood level, and neighborhoods differ in age distribution, household size, and healthcare access. The relationship at the neighborhood level may not reflect the causal effect on individuals.
claim: If we increase mask usage in a neighborhood, respiratory illness will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Neighborhood demographics (age distribution, household density)
Healthcare access and testing intensity differences across neighborhoods
Socioeconomic status and occupation mix affecting exposure risk

causal_structure: Associations at the group (neighborhood) level can be driven by between-group differences and do not necessarily equal the individual-level causal effect of masking.
key_insight: Group-level correlations can mislead about individual-level causality (ecological fallacy).
hidden_timestamp: Is the conclusion about individuals based only on neighborhood-level averages without individual-level linkage or adjustment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level data show that, within the same neighborhood and risk profile, individuals who increase mask use have lower illness risk, the causal claim becomes plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the evidence is only neighborhood averages, differences in demographics and risk environments can explain the pattern without a causal effect of mask usage at the individual level.

wise_refusal: We can't infer that increasing individuals' mask use will reduce illness from neighborhood averages alone because group-level differences may drive the association.
gold_rationale: Ecological correlations can arise from confounding between groups and need not reflect individual causal effects.

scenario: A school district observes that schools with higher average hours of homework assigned per week (X) also have higher average standardized test scores (Y). The superintendent claims assigning more homework will raise test scores for students. But schools differ in resources, student intake, and teacher experience, and the analysis is based on school-level averages.
claim: Assigning more homework will increase students' test scores.
label: NO

Z: School resources and funding differences
Student socioeconomic composition and prior achievement
Teacher experience and curriculum rigor

causal_structure: School-level averages mix individual effects with between-school differences; higher-achieving schools may assign more homework and also score higher for other reasons.
key_insight: A school-level pattern does not prove that giving each student more homework causes higher scores.
hidden_timestamp: Is the evidence only at the school-average level rather than tracking individual students' homework changes and outcomes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If within the same school (or via randomized assignment), increasing homework for comparable students leads to higher scores, then a causal effect is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis uses only school averages, differences in intake and resources can explain the association without homework causing score gains.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude more homework causes higher scores from school-average data because differences between schools may drive both homework levels and test performance.
gold_rationale: Ecological fallacy: group-level correlations can misrepresent individual-level causal relationships.

scenario: A report shows that cities with higher bike-lane density per capita (X) have lower citywide traffic fatality rates (Y). Advocates claim that building more bike lanes will reduce an individual driver's crash risk. But the data are city-level and cities differ in public transit availability, enforcement, and driving culture.
claim: Building more bike lanes will reduce individuals' traffic fatality risk.
label: NO

Z: Public transit availability and overall vehicle miles traveled
Traffic enforcement intensity and speed limits
Urban design and driving culture differences across cities

causal_structure: City-level infrastructure correlates with many other city traits; aggregate rates cannot directly identify the individual-level causal effect of lanes.
key_insight: Inferring individual causal effects from aggregate statistics can be wrong when group composition differs.
hidden_timestamp: Is the causal claim about individuals derived solely from citywide aggregate comparisons rather than individual exposure and risk data?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a within-city policy rollout (or individual-level exposure data) shows crash risk declines for comparable road users after lane expansion, the claim becomes plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only city-level correlations are used, differences like transit use and enforcement can produce the pattern without lanes being the causal driver at the individual level.

wise_refusal: We can't infer that bike lanes reduce each individual's crash risk from citywide averages alone because cities differ in many factors that affect fatalities.
gold_rationale: Aggregate correlations can reflect confounding by city-level characteristics rather than individual causal effects.

scenario: A company compares departments and finds that departments with higher average meeting hours per employee (X) also report higher average employee engagement scores (Y). Leadership concludes scheduling more meetings will raise engagement. But engagement may be driven by leadership quality, and meeting hours are measured as a department average rather than at the individual level.
claim: Scheduling more meetings will increase employee engagement.
label: NO

Z: Leadership quality and team cohesion differences by department
Role composition (customer-facing vs engineering) affecting meeting needs
Survey response patterns differing across departments

causal_structure: Between-department differences can generate an aggregate association that does not imply that increasing meetings for an individual increases their engagement.
key_insight: Department-level associations can be driven by department traits rather than causal effects on individuals.
hidden_timestamp: Is the conclusion drawn from department-level averages without showing that individuals given more meetings become more engaged?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individuals are randomly assigned to increased meeting exposure (or a policy change within the same department) and engagement rises, the causal claim becomes plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only department-level averages are compared, leadership and role mix can explain higher engagement without meetings causing it.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude more meetings cause higher engagement from department averages because department-level differences may drive both meeting time and engagement.
gold_rationale: Ecological inference can fail when group composition and confounders differ across groups.

scenario: A patient starts a new allergy medication (X) and two weeks later reports fewer symptoms (Y). But the report does not clearly specify whether symptoms improved after starting the medication or whether symptoms were already improving before the start date due to the pollen season ending.
claim: The new allergy medication caused the patient's symptoms to decrease.
label: NO

Y.name: Severity of allergy symptoms over two weeks

Z: Timing of pollen exposure changes across the two weeks
Other concurrent treatments (nasal spray, antihistamines)
Natural symptom variation over the allergy season

causal_structure: Without clear time ordering, symptom improvement could precede medication initiation or coincide with an external seasonal decline.
key_insight: A causal claim needs a clear temporal order: X must occur before Y changes.
hidden_timestamp: Did symptom improvement occur only after the medication start date (with a documented baseline), or was it already improving beforehand?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If symptoms were stable or worsening before the start date and then consistently improved after starting the medication (with no other changes), the medication could plausibly have caused the improvement.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If symptoms were already improving before the medication started or pollen exposure dropped around the same time, the improvement cannot be attributed to the medication.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the medication caused improvement because the timing is unclear and symptoms may have improved before starting it or due to seasonal changes.
gold_rationale: Ambiguous temporal ordering undermines causal attribution in before/after observations.

scenario: A company offers a midday stretching break (X) and later that quarter reports fewer employee-reported neck pain complaints (Y). However, the report does not document whether the reduction started after the stretching program began or whether complaints were already declining due to seasonal workload changes or a prior ergonomics upgrade.
claim: Introducing the stretching break caused neck pain complaints to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Introducing a daily midday stretching break

Y.name: Rate of employee-reported neck pain complaints

Z: Seasonal workload variation affecting strain and reporting
Prior changes like new chairs/monitors rolled out earlier
Reporting habits shifting over the quarter

causal_structure: Without a clear pre/post timeline, Y may have changed before X or due to other coincident changes.
key_insight: Before/after claims require a well-defined start time and outcome trajectory.
hidden_timestamp: When exactly did neck-pain complaints start decreasing relative to the stretching break start date?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If complaints were stable before the program and then dropped only after the stretching break began (with no other interventions), the program could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If complaints were already trending down before the stretching break or other changes occurred earlier, the decrease cannot be attributed to stretching.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute fewer complaints to the stretching break because the timing of the decline relative to the rollout isn't established.
gold_rationale: Temporal ambiguity prevents distinguishing treatment effects from pre-existing trends or earlier interventions.

scenario: A person enables a phone's new battery-saver mode (X) and later notices their phone lasts longer between charges (Y). But they also began traveling the same week and used the phone less, and it is unclear whether battery life improved immediately after enabling the feature or only after the behavior change.
claim: Enabling battery-saver mode caused the phone to last longer between charges.
label: NO

Z: Usage changes due to travel (screen time, GPS, video calls)
Network conditions (poor reception increases battery drain)
App updates or background process changes around the same time

causal_structure: Battery life changes depend on both X and concurrent time-varying factors; unclear ordering and co-occurring changes confound attribution.
key_insight: If other changes happened around the same time, you need clear timing and control to claim causality.
hidden_timestamp: Did battery life improve immediately after enabling battery-saver, before any usage changes occurred?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If phone usage and conditions remained comparable and battery life improved right after enabling the mode, the mode could be the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If usage or conditions changed at the same time and the timing of improvement isn't tied to enabling the mode, the longer battery life cannot be attributed to the mode.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude battery-saver mode caused longer battery life because other time-varying factors changed and the timing of improvement isn't clear.
gold_rationale: Temporal ambiguity with concurrent behavior changes makes before/after causal claims unreliable.

scenario: A person starts drinking chamomile tea nightly (X) and later reports better sleep quality (Y). But the timeline is vague: they also changed work shifts that month, and it's unclear whether sleep improved after starting tea or after the schedule stabilized.
claim: Drinking chamomile tea nightly caused sleep quality to improve.
label: NO

Z: Work-shift change and schedule stabilization
Stress level changes across the month
Other sleep hygiene changes (screen time, exercise)

causal_structure: The outcome may have improved due to shift stabilization or stress reduction; without clear temporal ordering relative to X, causality is unclear.
key_insight: A clear intervention start and outcome trajectory are necessary to establish temporal precedence.
hidden_timestamp: Did sleep quality improve only after the first nights of chamomile tea, before the work-shift effects resolved?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sleep was consistently poor before tea and improved immediately after starting tea while work shifts and other factors stayed the same, tea could plausibly help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sleep improved after the schedule stabilized or alongside other changes and timing is unclear, the improvement cannot be attributed to tea.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude chamomile tea caused better sleep because the timeline is unclear and major schedule changes occurred around the same time.
gold_rationale: Temporal ambiguity prevents attributing changes to the intervention instead of coincident time-varying factors.

scenario: People who adopted a new low-sugar diet (X) are surveyed six months later about how many sugary snacks they ate before the diet and how many they eat now (Y). Diet adopters report a large reduction and claim the diet program caused it. However, participants may misremember their prior snack frequency or report what they think is socially desirable, and the outcome is entirely based on recall.
claim: The low-sugar diet program caused people to eat fewer sugary snacks.
label: NO

Y.name: Change in sugary snack consumption (self-reported by recall)

Z: Biased recall of pre-diet snack frequency
Social desirability bias in self-reported current snacks
Differential motivation among program adopters

causal_structure: Exposure status affects how participants remember and report past behavior, creating differential recall that can mimic an effect.
key_insight: When outcomes rely on memory of prior behavior, exposure can bias reporting, producing spurious before/after differences.
hidden_timestamp: Were pre-program snack levels measured prospectively (at baseline) or reconstructed later from memory after joining the program?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If baseline snack consumption was recorded before program adoption (e.g., food logs) and post-adoption consumption was measured similarly, a true reduction could support causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If participants reconstructed pre-diet snack intake from memory after adopting the diet, recall and desirability biases can explain the reported reduction without a causal effect.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the program caused fewer snacks because the key outcome depends on retrospective recall, which can differ by program participation.
gold_rationale: Recall bias can create apparent improvements when participants misremember or selectively report past behavior after an intervention.

scenario: After completing a safety training course (X), employees are asked to recall how often they violated safety protocols in the months before training and how often they violate them now (Y). Trainees report fewer past violations and fewer current violations, and management concludes training caused safer behavior. But trainees may underreport past behavior or reshape memories to align with training expectations.
claim: Safety training caused employees to violate protocols less often.
label: NO

Y.name: Change in protocol violations (self-reported by recall)

Z: Post-training reinterpretation of what counts as a 'violation'
Underreporting of past violations due to social desirability
Differential memory accuracy across employees

causal_structure: Training changes salience and reporting norms, biasing retrospective reports of past and current violations.
key_insight: If the outcome depends on participants remembering and admitting past behavior, the intervention can change reporting rather than behavior.
hidden_timestamp: Were protocol violations measured objectively (e.g., audits) before and after training, or only via retrospective self-report after training?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If independent audits recorded violations before and after training and violations decreased among trained employees compared to untrained controls, training could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If changes are based on trainees' retrospective self-reports, recall and desirability biases can explain the apparent reduction.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute fewer violations to training because the evidence relies on retrospective self-report that can be biased by training participation.
gold_rationale: Recall bias and shifting definitions can create spurious improvements in self-reported behavior following an intervention.

scenario: Parents whose children joined a new after-school sports program (X) are later asked to recall how many hours their child exercised per week before the program and how many hours they exercise now (Y). Parents report a large increase and conclude the program caused more exercise. But parents may overestimate baseline inactivity or selectively remember details after committing to the program.
claim: The after-school sports program caused children to exercise more each week.
label: NO

Z: Parents' biased recall of pre-program activity levels
Social desirability in reporting children's activity
Seasonal changes in outdoor play opportunities

causal_structure: Program participation influences memory and reporting of baseline activity, confounding before/after comparisons based on recall.
key_insight: Retrospective baseline measures can be systematically biased after an intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Was baseline exercise recorded before enrollment (e.g., activity tracker logs) or reconstructed later from parents' memory?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If baseline activity was measured prospectively (e.g., tracker data) and post-enrollment activity increased relative to comparable non-enrolled children, the program could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If baseline was recalled after enrollment, biased memory and desirability can inflate the apparent increase without a true causal effect.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the program caused more exercise because the key comparison relies on parents recalling pre-program activity, which can be biased after enrollment.
gold_rationale: Recall bias can distort baseline measures and create spurious pre/post differences.

scenario: People who started a mindfulness app (X) are surveyed months later and asked to recall how often they felt anxious before starting and how often they feel anxious now (Y). Users report a big drop and claim the app reduced anxiety. But recall of prior anxiety can be distorted, and people who paid for the app may report improvements consistent with expectations.
claim: Using the mindfulness app caused anxiety to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Starting regular use of a mindfulness app

Y.name: Change in anxiety frequency (self-reported by recall)

Z: Distorted recall of pre-app anxiety levels
Expectation/placebo effects influencing self-report
Concurrent life changes (job stress, therapy, sleep) over months

causal_structure: App adoption affects recall and reporting of baseline anxiety, and long time gaps allow other changes to influence outcomes.
key_insight: Without prospectively measured baseline, improvements may reflect biased memory and expectations rather than causal effects.
hidden_timestamp: Was anxiety measured before app use with the same instrument, or only reconstructed later from memory after app adoption?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If anxiety was measured prospectively pre-app and post-app using the same validated scale, and users improve more than comparable non-users, a causal effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If baseline anxiety is based on retrospective recall after months of app use, recall and expectation biases can explain the reported drop.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute decreased anxiety to the app because the comparison relies on retrospective recall and may reflect reporting biases and other changes over time.
gold_rationale: Recall bias and expectancy effects can create apparent improvements in self-reported mental health outcomes post-intervention.

scenario: A team compares employees who use a new focus-music playlist during work (X) to those who do not. Playlist users appear to complete more tasks per day (Y). But people who choose to use the playlist tend to have more demanding roles and higher baseline conscientiousness, which also increases task completion.
claim: Using the focus-music playlist causes employees to complete more tasks per day.
label: NO

X.name: Using the focus-music playlist while working

Z: Baseline conscientiousness/self-discipline
Role demands and task assignment differences
Manager expectations and performance incentives

causal_structure: A common cause (motivation/role demands) influences both choosing the playlist and higher productivity, confounding the observed association.
key_insight: Self-selection into an exposure can reflect underlying traits that also affect the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees randomly assigned to use the playlist, or did motivated/high-performing employees disproportionately choose it?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees were randomly assigned to use the playlist (or matched on role and baseline productivity) and still completed more tasks, the playlist could plausibly increase productivity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If playlist use is self-selected and correlated with motivation or role demands, the observed difference can be explained by confounding rather than a causal effect.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the playlist caused higher productivity because employees who choose it may already be more motivated or have different roles.
gold_rationale: Confounding by self-selection can generate associations that are not causal.

scenario: People who buy a meal-prep subscription (X) have lower average BMI after six months (Y) than those who do not. The company claims the subscription causes weight loss. However, people who choose meal-prep tend to be more health-conscious and already dieting, which affects both purchasing and weight outcomes.
claim: Buying the meal-prep subscription causes people to lose weight.
label: NO

Z: Baseline health consciousness and dieting intent
Exercise habits and lifestyle routines
Baseline BMI and prior weight trajectory

causal_structure: Health motivation influences both the decision to subscribe and the likelihood of losing weight, creating confounding.
key_insight: When exposure is chosen, underlying preferences and behaviors can drive both exposure and outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Were subscribers already on a weight-loss trajectory or more health-motivated before subscribing compared to non-subscribers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If subscription access were randomly assigned (or carefully adjusted for baseline motivation, diet, and exercise) and subscribers still lose more weight, a causal effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If subscribers are systematically more health-conscious or already dieting, the lower BMI can be explained by confounding rather than the subscription causing weight loss.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute weight loss to the meal-prep subscription because subscribers may differ in motivation and lifestyle from non-subscribers.
gold_rationale: Confounding by baseline motivation and behaviors can explain the observed differences in BMI.

scenario: A neighborhood watch group installs more outdoor lighting on their street (X). After six months, reported theft incidents (Y) are lower than on nearby streets without the lighting. The group claims the lighting reduced theft. However, the street that installed lighting also has higher household income and more residents working from home, which can reduce theft risk independently of lighting.
claim: Installing outdoor lighting reduced theft incidents on the street.
label: NO

Y.name: Number of theft incidents reported over six months

Z: Household income and property security features
Resident presence (work-from-home, neighborhood activity)
Police patrol frequency and reporting behavior

causal_structure: Neighborhood characteristics influence both installing lighting and theft risk, confounding the association between lighting and theft reduction.
key_insight: Community-level interventions are often correlated with baseline safety and resources that also affect outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Did the street differ from comparison streets in baseline wealth, security practices, or resident presence before installing lighting?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If lighting were installed in a randomized rollout (or compared with closely matched streets on baseline safety and resources) and theft drops more where lighting is added, causality is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the lighting street is wealthier or more monitored than others, those confounders can explain lower theft without lighting being the cause.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude lighting caused fewer thefts because streets that choose lighting may already be safer or have different resources and monitoring.
gold_rationale: Confounding by neighborhood resources and baseline safety can produce apparent intervention effects.

scenario: A clinic gives patients with diabetes a new continuous glucose monitor (CGM) system (X). Three months later, the clinic reports better average glucose control (Y) among CGM users than non-users. However, CGM users have frequent measurements that detect short spikes and allow timely corrections, while non-users have infrequent finger-stick logs that miss spikes and are sometimes back-filled, making outcomes not directly comparable.
claim: Providing CGMs caused patients to have better glucose control over three months.
label: NO

X.name: Receiving a continuous glucose monitor system

Z: Different measurement frequency and capture of glucose spikes (CGM vs finger-stick logs)
Selective logging or back-filling of finger-stick measurements
Baseline self-management motivation differences between adopters and non-adopters

causal_structure: Exposure changes the measurement instrument and sampling process for Y, creating differential measurement error and comparability issues.
key_insight: If the exposure changes how the outcome is measured, observed differences may be measurement artifacts rather than true outcome changes.
hidden_timestamp: Are glucose outcomes computed from the same measurement method, frequency, and rules for CGM users and non-users?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both groups' glucose control is assessed using the same standardized measurement protocol (e.g., lab A1c) and CGM users still improve more, a causal effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If CGM users are measured continuously while non-users rely on sparse logs, differences may reflect measurement bias and non-comparable metrics rather than CGMs causing better control.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude CGMs caused better control because the outcome is measured differently across groups, which can create spurious differences.
gold_rationale: Differential measurement by exposure status can mimic treatment effects even without true physiological differences.

scenario: A company introduces a new productivity tool that automatically tracks active keyboard and mouse time for users (X). Managers report that tool users show higher 'productive hours' (Y) than non-users. However, non-users' productive hours are estimated from weekly self-reports, while users' hours come from automated tracking, which counts activity differently and may inflate or deflate compared to self-report.
claim: Using the productivity tool caused employees to be productive for more hours each week.
label: NO

X.name: Using the productivity tool with automated activity tracking

Z: Different measurement instruments (automated tracking vs self-report)
Different definitions of 'productive time' (activity vs meaningful work)
Gaming behavior (mouse jiggling) among tracked users

causal_structure: Exposure determines the measurement method for Y; automated metrics are not comparable to self-reports and can shift the measured outcome.
key_insight: When measurement differs across groups, differences can reflect instrumentation rather than true behavioral change.
hidden_timestamp: Were productive hours measured using the same definition and instrument for both tool users and non-users?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both groups' productivity is measured using the same objective metric (or both use the same tracking rules) and users still improve, the tool could have a causal impact.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If users are measured by automated tracking while non-users are measured by self-report, the apparent difference may be a measurement artifact.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the tool caused higher productivity because the outcome is measured differently for users and non-users.
gold_rationale: Differential measurement can create apparent treatment effects even when true productivity is unchanged.

scenario: A group of people joins a gym that provides a free wearable tracker to new members (X). After two months, the gym reports members increased their daily steps (Y). However, those who joined and activated the wearable have step counts captured automatically, while those who did not activate it self-report steps using rough estimates, making the measured increase potentially an artifact of improved tracking rather than real behavior change.
claim: Joining the gym caused members to take more steps per day.
label: NO

X.name: Joining the gym and activating the provided wearable tracker

Y.name: Daily step count over two months

Z: Automatic step capture vs self-estimated steps (instrument difference)
Wearable compliance and data missingness patterns
Baseline activity differences among those who activate trackers

causal_structure: Activation of tracking changes measurement accuracy and frequency, creating differential outcome measurement by exposure status.
key_insight: Better measurement can look like improvement even if true behavior is unchanged.
hidden_timestamp: Are steps measured identically (same wearable, same wear-time rules) for all members regardless of gym enrollment/activation status?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If everyone’s steps are measured with the same wearable and wear-time rules before and after enrollment, a true step increase could support causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only exposed participants have objective step tracking while others estimate steps, the apparent increase can be due to measurement differences.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude gym membership caused more steps because step measurement differs across groups and may reflect tracking differences rather than real change.
gold_rationale: Differential instrumentation by exposure status can generate spurious effects.

scenario: A company introduces a bonus tied to a simple metric: number of support tickets closed per day (X = exposure to the new incentive scheme). After the change, the average number of tickets closed (Y) increases, and leadership claims the incentive improved customer support outcomes. However, the incentive may change behavior in unintended ways: employees might close tickets faster without resolving issues, causing repeat tickets and worse customer satisfaction.
claim: Introducing the ticket-closure bonus improved customer support outcomes.
label: NO

Y.name: Customer support outcomes (quality of issue resolution)

Z: Metric manipulation (closing without full resolution)
Shift in effort away from complex cases to easy-to-close cases
Customer satisfaction and repeat-contact rates not captured by closure count

causal_structure: X changes incentives and the pathway from effort to outcomes; improving the measured proxy (closures) may worsen the true outcome (resolution quality) via a different mechanism.
key_insight: Understanding the causal mechanism matters: optimizing a proxy can change behaviors along pathways that harm the real target outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Did the incentive increase true resolution quality (e.g., first-contact resolution, customer satisfaction), or only increase the closure count proxy?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If quality metrics (repeat-contact rate, satisfaction, audit scores) improve after introducing the bonus while controlling for volume, the incentive could improve outcomes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only closure counts increased and quality worsened or was not measured, the incentive may have changed the mechanism toward superficial closures rather than better support.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the bonus improved support outcomes because the incentive can change the mechanism, increasing closures while potentially reducing true resolution quality.
gold_rationale: Mechanism shifts and proxy optimization can produce misleading improvements in measured metrics without improving the underlying outcome.

scenario: A clinic gives patients a pamphlet encouraging daily weighing (X). After a month, patients show greater short-term weight fluctuations (Y) and the clinic claims the pamphlet made weight management worse. But daily weighing changes the measurement process and can reveal normal day-to-day variability that was previously unobserved, without changing true body composition.
claim: Encouraging daily weighing caused patients' weight to become more unstable.
label: NO

X.name: Encouragement to weigh daily (higher measurement frequency)

Z: Higher measurement frequency revealing natural fluctuation
Hydration and salt intake affecting daily weight readings
Scale calibration and measurement timing differences

causal_structure: X changes how often Y is observed; the apparent increase in variability may be due to the observation mechanism rather than true instability.
key_insight: Changing the measurement/observation mechanism can change observed outcomes even if the underlying state is unchanged.
hidden_timestamp: Was weight variability compared using the same measurement frequency and rules before and after the pamphlet intervention?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both before and after periods use the same measurement frequency and protocol and variability still increases, the intervention might have affected behavior or physiology.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If variability appears larger only because measurements became daily (revealing normal fluctuation), the change reflects the observation mechanism, not a causal worsening.
